dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Panoramic view of Monument Valley. Mighty towers of red s desert floor below. We hear only the sound of the wind. Then, distantly, singing. A tiny figure just visible to t riding a white horse, has cornered a huge archway of ston Close on the rider, Buster Scruggs. His white clothing an blindingly clean. He has one leg drawn up to rest on the on the leg. He strums as he sings, smiling. He finishes the song, holding the last note. Then he hook horn and picks up the reins. He addresses the camera as h

dialogues.speaker: BUSTER
dialogues.text: A song never fails to divert m’mind during a long day’s ride out here in the West, where distances’re great and the scenery monotonous. Additionally, m’pleasing baritone seems inspirit good ol’ Dan, keepin’ him in good heart through the day’s measure of hoofclops. Ain’t that right, Dan? A confirming Huntz Hall from the horse.

dialogues.speaker: BUSTER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Maybe y’all’ve heard a me, Buster Scruggs—known to some as the San Saba Songbird. I got other handles, nicknames, appelations and cognoments... He is reaching into his necessary bag and draws from it a of himself with his name printed beneath, and beneath tha

dialogues.speaker: BUSTER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: ... but this’n here I don’t consider t’be even halfways earned. I don’t hate m’fellow man even when he’s tiresome’n surly’n tries to cheat at poker. Why I figure that’s just the human material... He crumples the handbill and tosses it over his shoulder.  BUSTER (CONT’D) ... and himmet finds in it cause for anger’n dismay is just a fool for expectin’ better. Ain’t that right, Dan? Another Huntz Hall.

dialogues.speaker: BUSTER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: ... Well folks, unless I grievously misremember, there’s a little cantina on the other side of yon rimrocks, and if I’m in luck itll be customers there amenable to drawin’ up in a circle round a deck acards. Git up now! Haw!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door creaks open and Buster Scruggs takes in the humb pan shows a rude small-windowed place with rough wood app bar. The few hard-looking men drinking there have stopped Buster Scruggs claps his hat against his clothes, raising bartender.

dialogues.speaker: BUSTER
dialogues.text: Like me a splash a whiskey ter wash this traildust offen my gullet’n keep m’singin’ voice in fettle. The bartender slowly shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: BARTENDER
dialogues.text: Dry county. Whiskey’s illegal. Buster looks around at the other customers.

dialogues.speaker: BUSTER
dialogues.text: What’re they drinkin’?

dialogues.speaker: BARTENDER
dialogues.text: Whiskey. A beat during which Buster tries to square the informatio BARTENDER (CONT’D) ... They’s outlaws.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well don’t let m’white duds’n pleasant demeanor fool ya, I too have been known to violate the statutes a man—and not a few a the laws a the Almighty. The hardest of the hard men seated nearby gives a derisiv

dialogues.speaker: HARD MAN
dialogues.text: Hew ain’t no outlaw. Buster turns to face him. The man, chewing a toothpick, o HARD MAN (CONT’D) ... And we don’t drink with tinhorns. Buster meets the taunt with a smile.

dialogues.speaker: BUSTER
dialogues.text: Sir, it seems you are no better a judge of human bein’s than you are a specimen of one. Just on a brief inventory I’d say you could use yourself a shave and a brighter disposition and lastly if you don’t mind me aspersin’ your friends a better class of drinkin’ buddies. The man grunts. His companions grunt, looking at Buster i hard man, mouth clamped on his toothpick, slowly rises, g holster. Buster is completely relaxed, hands at his sides. The har

dialogues.speaker: HARD MAN
dialogues.text: Your shootin’ iron work? In less time than it takes to tell, Buster draws and shoo his gun and reholsters it. The hard man, a neat hole in his forehead, stands on his not yet aware that he is dead.

dialogues.speaker: BUSTER
dialogues.text: Appears to do, yes. The hard man drops.  His friends stare, stunned. As one, they leap to their feet hauling out guns. Buster redraws his and, fanning the hammer, lays the men He cocks the hammer one last time and for some reason whi backward under his left armpit. He holds that odd posture for a long moment, then slowly over his left shoulder. Behind him, the bartender is frozen in the act of reachin the bar. The two men have eye contact. Buster winks at the bartender and—BLAM!—fires. One man from among the group at the table is not dead. He door of the cantina. Buster, surprised, looks at the came

dialogues.speaker: BUSTER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Appears that the vitals of this lucky sonofagun remain unpunctured—sloppy shootin’ on my part! The man’s groaning and scraping sounds are the only noise

dialogues.speaker: BUSTER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: ... But the nearest human habitation is a day’s ride away, three days on foot, ‘n lord alone knows how many on your belly. I suspect that wolves’n gila monsters’ll save me on ammo. Adios, amigo. Puts me in mind of a song...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Buster fetches up onto his horse and pulls out his guitar Cowboy” as he sets out from the cantina. Behind him we ca himself out the doorway into the vast dustiness of the de

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Buster finishes the song as he travels the town’s one dus

dialogues.speaker: BUSTER
dialogues.text: Frenchman’s Gulch. This town is new to me. But I ain’t never knowed nothin’ French to be dry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Buster enters. It is everything he could have hoped for: somewhere a piano playing, and several tables set about w place is crowded with drinkers, poker-players, hell-raise

dialogues.speaker: VOICE
dialogues.text: Hang on, son... The voice belongs to a man behind a small counter by the indicate a small sign on the facing of the counter: CHECK

dialogues.speaker: VOICE, (CONTD)
dialogues.text: . House policy. Buster amiably unhitches his gunbelt.

dialogues.speaker: BUSTER
dialogues.text: Here’s the six-shooters... He bends down to pull a derringer from each boot. BUSTER (CONT’D) ... Now’re you gonna be wantin’ the sefiiorita pistols as well?

dialogues.speaker: CHECKER
dialogues.text: Everthang, ‘cludin’ knives.

dialogues.speaker: BUSTER
dialogues.text: Never partial to knives. I ain’t much for workin’ in close. As he strolls away:

dialogues.speaker: BUSTER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: ... Feel a bit naked but I guess with ever one similarly disadvantaged there’s scant chance of misadventure. Hello! He is reacting to a man rising at a nearby table and tos

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: T’m out. As he stalks away Buster slides into his chair.

dialogues.speaker: BUSTER
dialogues.text: This is well timed. You gentlemen mind if I take his spot? A surly man directly across answers:

dialogues.speaker: ANGRY MAN
dialogues.text: Iffen you play his hand. Buster picks up the five face-down cards and looks: aces

dialogues.speaker: BUSTER
dialogues.text: I would prefer not to. Another man, in a vest and with a small neatly waxed must

dialogues.speaker: FRENCHMAN
dialogues.text: It is too late. You have regarded ze cards.

dialogues.speaker: SURLY MAN
dialogues.text: You seen ‘em. You play ‘em.

dialogues.speaker: BUSTER
dialogues.text: Tain’t anted.

dialogues.speaker: FRENCHMAN
dialogues.text: Ze uzzer hombre anted.

dialogues.speaker: SURLY MAN
dialogues.text: You seen ‘em. You play ‘em.

dialogues.speaker: BUSTER
dialogues.text: And what if I don’t? The surly man rises. He has a gun in his hand. He aims it

dialogues.speaker: SURLY MAN
dialogues.text: Play them cards, fancy dan. The table—the entire establishment—falls silent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can’t no one compel a man to engage in recreation, and certainly not a sonofagun as ill-humored as yourself. He rises slowly, holding his hands away from his sides as

dialogues.speaker: BUSTER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: ... Second place, m’horse’s Dan, I’m Buster—Buster Scruggs. And third place—

dialogues.speaker: SURLY MAN
dialogues.text: Buster Scruggs? The Runt from Reata Pass! He pulls back the hammer on the gun, smiling. SURLY MAN (CONT’D) ... And dis-pistoled! Buster looks at the gun, looks at the man.

dialogues.speaker: BUSTER
dialogues.text: I do hail from Reata Pass which is in the county of San Saba, bein’ the which-a-why “The San Saba Songbird” is m’sobriquet of preference. But right now I would appreciate it if you would place your weapon in that receptacle by the swingin doors, which concealin’ it on your person in the first place was a violation of the rules of this establishment and an offense against local norms. The surly man chuckles. He aims the gun toward the middle

dialogues.speaker: SURLY MAN
dialogues.text: And ifPn I don’t? Buster raises one leg and stamps smartly on the near side up, knocking the man’s gunhand upward to discharge into h The table settles and the hand drops, still clutching the half shot away. Buster stamps two more times in quick succession, slammi more shots. The Frenchman is spattered with blood. The ceiling gets a The man lingers on his feet long enough for us to look at drops. A hard man nearby looks on in shock. He is Ike.

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: Joey...? He rushes over to the body. Buster addresses the camera.

dialogues.speaker: BUSTER
dialogues.text: T’m not a devious man by nature but when you’re unarmed your tactics might gotta be downright Archimedean. He looks around.

dialogues.speaker: BUSTER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: .. Now what happened to the music? The piano starts up again. Buster goes over to place a fo join the bowlered, cigar-chomping piano player in a rauco Gambler.” The whole saloonful of rakehells and bawds join We intercut Ike kneeling beside the face-shot gambler, cr to mop the ever- flowing blood from his face with a banda weeping, to wring blood from the bandana. It is sad visua upbeat song. Finally Ike’s keening voice breaks up the mu

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: Joe! Surly Joe! He’s gawn! We’ve a-lost’m! He lurches tearfully over to Buster.

dialogues.speaker: IKE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: ... You kilt my brother, you cowardly, sonofabitch! Gunned ‘im down when he wasn’t hardly lookin’!

dialogues.speaker: BUSTER
dialogues.text: I can cut you a little slack, grievin’ as you are, but the fact is Buster Scruggs don’t shoot nobody in the back and that sorry sack a bones was more in the nature of a suicide.  10. Ike is taken aback.

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: You’re Buster Scruggs?! The West Texas Twit? For the first time Buster loses his smile. Everyone around tenses. Buster clears his throat and, with an effort, recovers hi

dialogues.speaker: BUSTER
dialogues.text: Presume you meant to say “The West Texas Tit”—on account of that p’ticular bird’s mellifluous warble.

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: Call yerself any damn name you please! I wanna see you outside— wearin’ iron!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Buster is stepping down off the boardwalk into the street

dialogues.speaker: BUSTER
dialogues.text: Things have a way of escalatin’ out here in the West with one thing leadin’ to another, but I think I can make pretty short work of this ramified ol’ sonofagun. In the deep background, planted in the middle of the stre

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: Scruggs! Scru-u-u-u-u-uggs! I’m a-callin’ you out!

dialogues.speaker: BUSTER
dialogues.text: Well hang in there, pardner, I just need to buckle on this toolbelt here. He finishes doing so. Ike is poised, right hand hovering Buster smiles at him.  11.

dialogues.speaker: BUSTER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: ... Are ya ready?

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: Ready!

dialogues.speaker: BUSTER
dialogues.text: Are ya set?

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: Set!

dialogues.speaker: BUSTER
dialogues.text: Ya need you a count?

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: Na’sir! In less time than it takes to tell, Buster draws and fire drop. He raises his right hand—gouting blood from where t

dialogues.speaker: BUSTER
dialogues.text: Hard to trigger with them other fingers, but... He fans the hammer, shooting four more times. Tke’s hand: his other three fingers are shot off in quick thumb. On the dusty street, the digits plop to the ground.

dialogues.speaker: BUSTER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: .. you cain’t be too careful. Ike, screaming, looks at his stumpy hand spewing blood. H with his left hand for his right-holstered gun.

dialogues.speaker: BUSTER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Uh-oh. Looks like when they made this fella they forgot to put in the quit! Lemme see here, five fingers at a bullet a piece, I ain’t got but the one bullet left. For some reason Buster turns to face the other way up the screaming Ike.  12. Close on Buster we can see Ike small in the background, t across his body to clumsily start withdrawing his gun. BUSTER (CONT’D) Sure hope I don’t miss. Buster takes a small mirror out of his pocket with his le in as he aims his gun upside-down and backwards over his

dialogues.speaker: BUSTER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: ... Lesee, his heart’d be on the left side but the mirror puts it right, cepting for we is facing the same way and the gun is upside down. So, um... Ike has his gun out and raises it, screaming.

dialogues.speaker: BUSTER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: . maybe it’s best not to play it fancy.

dialogues.speaker: BAM
dialogues.text: Ike pitches backward into the street. There is a hole in Buster Scruggs enters a low shot to gaze down at the body still holds and, as he starts to pocket it:

dialogues.speaker: BUSTER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Cause for reflection—heh-heh. Well, this whole entire episode puts me in mind of a song. He sucks in his breath but before it can issue out in son faint but sweet. Surprised, Buster looks around for the source of the sing Riding up the road is a handsome young man accompanying h sings. Buster walks over to meet the oncoming rider who finishes guitar.

dialogues.speaker: THE KID
dialogues.text: Buster Scruggs?  13.

dialogues.speaker: BUSTER
dialogues.text: The same. You got a mighty sweet singin’ voice, pardner.

dialogues.speaker: THE KID
dialogues.text: That’s high praise—from the San Saba Songbird, Herald of Demise. Buster smiles, flattered on a point of pride. The rider r

dialogues.speaker: THE KID, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: ... Mr. Scruggs, I been huntin’ you on account a they say you’re the one to beat, a-singin’ and a-slingin’ guns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A minute later. Buster sadly shakes his head as he paces bullets into his six-shooter.

dialogues.speaker: BUSTER
dialogues.text: Another young fella with something to prove. Behind him in the background a couple of men are dragging ankles, and the young man is taking his place in the midd

dialogues.speaker: BUSTER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I gotta set m’self up in the undertaking bidnis—stop doin’ all the skillwork so’s another man can profit. He turns, having reloaded and holstered his gun. He murmu new antagonist: BUSTER (CONT’D) .. But then, do I wanna wear a black suit. From off:

dialogues.speaker: THE KID
dialogues.text: You need a count? Buster chuckles.  14.

dialogues.speaker: BUSTER
dialogues.text: Na’sir—

dialogues.speaker: BLAM
dialogues.text: Buster blinks, puzzled.

dialogues.speaker: BUSTER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: ... Hold ona second. He looks down. His right hand is relaxed, empty, next to his still holst He looks up the street. The young man stands set in place, gunhand extended befor counterbalance, smoke wafting from his gunbarrel. Buster squints at him. He looks down at his own chest whe A red droplet hits the snowy white of his tunic. Buster tries to sort this out. He reaches for his hat. He holds it up before himself to inspect it. The front of He tips the hat, front brim upward, so as to look inside. The inside back of the crown shows an exit hole. Sprayed brain.

dialogues.speaker: BUSTER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Well now that ain’t good. He looks up. The young man is still planted. The gunsmoke has dissipat Buster takes out his handmirror. He examines himself in i There is a hole centered high in his forehead. In the reflection, he drops away, quickly followed by han From behind the young man’s hip: he twirls and holsters h see the soles of Buster Scruggs boots and his body stretc High on Buster Scruggs, on his back in the street, sightl Oddly, his voice continues in the same present tone:  15.

dialogues.speaker: BUSTER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I guess I shoulda seen this comin’... The young man enters a low shot to gaze down at the body. Back to the high shot of Buster. While his corpse remains blood begins to pool out from under his head, his soul be body in the same white get-up but with wings sprouting ou transparent, continues the speech:

dialogues.speaker: BUSTER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: ... Roam and ramble though you might, eventually you’re gonna come acrost some sonofagun who sings a little sweeter and draws a little faster. Buster’s soul starts to sing, harmonizing with the sweet- the verse, the cowboy continues singing but Buster’s soul

dialogues.speaker: BUSTER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: ... I don’t know as I believe in a divinity shapin’ our ends and numberin’ our days. But I do believe I’m a-headed for a hereafter... The young cowboy goes over to his rail-hitched horse, sti

dialogues.speaker: BUSTER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: ... Why heck, ifthere warn’t a place where men ain’t low-down and poker’s played fair, then what’re all the songs about? The young man unhitches his horse and swings aboard.

dialogues.speaker: BUSTER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: ... I b’lieve the music comes from that higher place... The young man swings his guitar up and heads out, riding pommel and his guitar resting on the leg, strumming as he We are rising higher, higher, with the ascending soul of  16. BUSTER (CONT’D) ... An’ at’s where I’m off to, to trade my gui-tar for a lyre and sing those sweet songs where they ain’t no clinkers to sour the spell and cain’t no gunplay inter-trude. Tl see all of you sonofaguns in the bye and bye and we can sing them sweet airs together, and shake our heads over all that meanness in the used-to-be. He resumes his harmony part as the young cowboy recedes b figure entering the vast desert, his distant voice echoin As the singing voices fade into the sound of a moaning wi The last lines of our tale in print on the page, which is the next story:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: “Pan-shot!” cried the old man.  17. Near Algodones | nder the wind we hear now the steady clunk of a piece o heavy object. Turning again to another full page illustration: We are looking across a dusty expanse toward a low-slung alone in an endless expanse of high desert. In the mid-foreground a short, fat man in a dirty union s prancing, almost airborne. He holds a double-barreled sho pans are draped over his body, twine threading the handle helmetlike upside-down on his head. We travel down to the caption below the illustration: “Pan-shot!” cried the trapper. Dissolve from the illustration to:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are panning the horizon. It is fat, windswept, vast, e It is the western edge of the Great Plains. Our pan eventually finds and settles on a small adobe bui measureless horizon. A weathered wooden sign above its door identifies it as t & TRUST OF TUCUMCARI. Swinging beneath it and clunking against the top of the d sign, apparently put up as afterthought: 4nd Notary. Taking it in, eyes crinkling against the wind, is a man i holding the reins of a mount that stands behind him. From somewhere, a creaking sound. The man’s eyes shift: A well. The bucket suspended over it creaks back and fort jagged scrapwood is nailed to its canopy: BAD WATER. The horse nervously nickers. The cowboy drops the reins a  18.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cowboy enters. The one-room structure is empty except for a trapper with behind the teller’s bars, hands planted on the counter. H black sleevegarters. The cowboy walks to the counter, spurs jingling.

dialogues.speaker: COWBOY
dialogues.text: Awful big name for a little place like this.

dialogues.speaker: TELLER
dialogues.text: It’s a comfort to the depositors. The cowboy looks around.

dialogues.speaker: COWBOY
dialogues.text: .. What depositors?

dialogues.speaker: TELLER
dialogues.text: Oh, we got folks from over Val Verde, Chloride, Tucumcari itself of course—why, the whole entire three-county area. Hell, we even had a run on the bank once’t, warnt purty. Had to hop up on the counter here with m’scattergun, talk the folks down. Well, that’s banking. He chuckles, shaking his head.

dialogues.speaker: TELLER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: ... Crazy business. Crazy business.

dialogues.speaker: COWBOY
dialogues.text: Ever been robbed?

dialogues.speaker: TELLER
dialogues.text: OOHH yeah, sure enough have. TWO times. Attempted, I should say. One fellow I shot dead— BINGO!—the other I held for the marshal, both his legs was shredded some, had to lock him in the vault there, marshal don’t come through but once’t a month and he’d just visited the previous week, had to billet the scamp for what, three weeks, applyin’ a poultice of wet leaves’n urine. He’s in Yuma now, bustin’ rocks, still a little grumpy from what they say. Fella by the name of Chevilly unless I misremember, said his papa was from Fr—France— Fr—from—fff...  19. His voice trails off and he stares in silence. The cowboy is pointing a six-gun at him. The prairie wind moans. The teller’s jaw, relieved of its service to speech, hang The cowboy tosses a burlap sack over the bars.

dialogues.speaker: COWBOY
dialogues.text: Money in the sack. The teller gazes owlishly. Finally he sighs and his jaw r

dialogues.speaker: TELLER
dialogues.text: ... Okay. Okay, ya got me, young feller, ya got me fair’n square. The large denominations... He is stooping behind the counter. His voice continues, o

dialogues.speaker: TELLER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: .. I gotta stoop fer... A silence. The cowboy frowns. The unmistakable clack of a shotgun-prime. The cowboy’s eyes widen. He takes a nimbly evasive step d ROAR!—wood from the base of the counter splinters outward standing. ROAR!—another explosion further along. The cowboy grabs the bars at one end of the counter and h perched on the counter lip, hugging the bars. The shotgun He scales the bars and drops to the counter’s far side. The shotgun has fallen silent. Drifting gunsmoke. Inside, no sound. Outside, the moan of the prairie wind. The cowboy looks down at the duckboards behind the counte Empty. The teller has fled—somewhere.  20. The cowboy drops to the back floor. His bootheels clomp a walks the cage’s length. He stoops, starts stuffing bills into his sack.

dialogues.speaker: DOOR
dialogues.text: Creaking open at the cut with a rusty-hinged whine. The cowboy peeks out the bank’s front door, sack in one h His point-of-view shows the great empty plain. His horse Wind moans. The bucket creaks over the well. The cowboy hesitates, tenses, and—pushes off, heading for BOOM!—a shotgun blast kicks up dirt at his feet and the c and tucks and rolls to take cover behind the well housing His horse nickers nervously and trots a few paces further tentatively stops—a good thirty yards away, over exposed The cowboy hisses at it and waves a hand inward. The horse looks at him speculatively. Its ears flick. The cowboy looks toward the windblown adobe structure. No Very present, the creak of the bucket over the well. The cowboy looks at the sack of money abandoned in no-man the mouth of the sack. Bills flutter and rise like bees l in the breeze. The adobe structure, still. The cowboy, tensed. The bank’s front door bursts open and the old teller boil waving his shotgun. There is now something strange about be clanking as he runs. The hunched cowboy fires at him over the well wall.

dialogues.speaker: TELLER
dialogues.text: Pan shot! The teller gallops on, cackling, anrd—BOOM!—fires his sho of the wellwall. The cowboy shoots again: CLANG!

dialogues.speaker: TELLER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Pan shot! The teller has pots and pans draped over his body, twine One large pot sits helmetlike upside-down on his head. The cowboy rises, firing—CLANG! CLANG! CLANG! BOOM! A shotgun blast smacks the cowboy’s shoulder and tw flying into the dust. He looks from his lost gun up toward the teller just as t a-clank, swinging his shotgun-butt up and at us to send u

dialogues.speaker: SLOW FADEIN
dialogues.text: A black figure. Soft-focused and gently rocking. An echoing voice:

dialogues.speaker: VOICE
dialogues.text: Do you have anything to say... Very close on the cowboy: his eyes squint open. He too is becalmed boat. The voice repeats, with a little less echo:

dialogues.speaker: VOICE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Do you have anything to say? The cowboy licks parched lips. A raspy:

dialogues.speaker: COWBOY
dialogues.text: ... What?  22. He works his eyes. The black figure comes slowly into focus. It is a man in He is in treeshade but the open prairie behind him bakes His gentle irregular movement comes from the shifting of

dialogues.speaker: MAN IN BLACK
dialogues.text: Do you have anything to say? Before sentence is carried out. Wider on the cowboy: there is a noose round his neck. Its treelimb overhead. The cowboy’s shoulders are back, his h bobbing matches the other man’s—he, too, sitting ahorse.

dialogues.speaker: COWBOY
dialogues.text: What’s... m’sentence? Guffaws. There are other men, four of them, also mounted. The man in black looks reprovingly at his companions, the

dialogues.speaker: MAN IN BLACK
dialogues.text: Son, we held you some proceedin’s here for attempted bank robbery. You was off yer nut feverish for most of the goin’s-on but it was a fair trial like we do here in New Mexico. These peers convicted ya, I pronounced a sentence of death, and we found us this tree. Now’s your opp’ tunity to speak your piece before sentence is carried out.

dialogues.speaker: COWBOY
dialogues.text: Well... He licks his lips.

dialogues.speaker: COWBOY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: ... That pan-covered sonofabitch back at the bank don’t hardly fight fair, in my opinion. The man in black nods respectfully.

dialogues.speaker: MAN IN BLACK
dialogues.text: Okay. That it?  23.

dialogues.speaker: COWBOY
dialogues.text: Well... I reckon it is. Silence. Creaking rope. One member of the posse has a thought:

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: Can I have yer horse? The cowboy considers. Another posse member pipes up:

dialogues.speaker: SECOND MAN
dialogues.text: No, me. The ad hoc judge looks from his posse to the cowboy.

dialogues.speaker: MAN IN BLACK
dialogues.text: You wanna give one of these boys yer horse? It’ll save scrappin’ over it after you’ve passed.

dialogues.speaker: COWBOY
dialogues.text: I don’t want any of ‘em to have it. The first man growls:

dialogues.speaker: MAN

A sashcord is pulled to unfurl a painted drop at the back drop shows a vaguely medieval castle, stone steps, battle Straw is scattered upon the makeshift stage. A roughhewn sawhorse-stand is scissored open and planted bound in burlap is wedged into it. Sashcord is pulled to lower a curtain before the stage, j housings. The candles are lit. Now people are gathering. They seat themselves on the gro murmuring in anticipation. The Irishman surveys the crowd. He pulls out a pocketwatc He considers. He repockets the watch. He grabs a piece of cord and starts to pull. The curtain: it starts to center-part, the two halves gat The crowd gasps.  33. Edwin Horatio Harrison is but head wrapped in a burlap tunic of sorts that is pinned at the He is wedged into the scissor-stand to face the crowd. He continues to declaim:

We see parts of various speeches—“ before me,” “Four-score and seven years ago,” “I met a tr Intercut is the listening crowd, rough men and rougher wo toward the stage, awed by the beauty of the poetry. The closing monologue is “Our revels now are ended.” Duri through the crowd with a hat, accepting money with murmur “God bless you,” etc.

In the pond stands a deer, a many-antlered buck. He dips Silver minnows waggle in the water in formation, feeding the deer drinking nearby. At the spout of the pond, where it feeds the stream, wate over the rocks that form the bottleneck, the spray glinti An owl perched at the top of a tall pine surveys the cany breeze springs up, giving the tree a bit of life. The owl we hear the distant sound of a singing voice.  42. The deer lifts its head from the pool and looks down-cany The stream disappears below a curtain of vegetation—brush trees—that closes off the view. Beyond that middleground composed of rising rockface. We are in a contained space, world, a box canyon. We hear the singing voice a little more clearly: we can n breeze in the trees:

The deer stares, water dripping from its muzzle, then bol The silver minnows dart away. The owl takes clumsy flight. They can hear clip-clopping horses’ feet now, down-canyon singing: VOICE (CONT’D) ... I kiss the dear fingers So toil-worn for me, Oh, god bless you and keep you...

Thus reassured he goes to the donkey and unhooks a shovel He climbs to the pond, eyeing the stream as he passes it. He dips his head to the pondwater and drinks. He raises his head and, as he absently wipes his chin wit at the stream. A staring beat and then with a grunt he rises and swipes ground.

dialogues.text: We'll see... we'll see... He goes to the most upstream point of where the sidehill He digs a small shovelful of soil from the bank and dumps at the side of the stream. Balanced over his heels he dip raises it out and swishes it. He keeps dipping the pan and swishing it and lighter soil away by the deft circular movement. He pauses the washing gravel with his fingers, then dips and swishes again to s A last swish and outflinging of water discloses only the lining the pan-bottom like paint. He looks at the pan. He raises it closer, squints.  44. In the middle of the black gunk, the tiniest golden speck No reaction from the man: stillness. He dips the pan twice more and swishes. He looks: Now, two gold specks. After a still beat he nods, then dips the pan up-and-down shakes it back and forth, cleaning it.

He has a farmer’s tan: very red neck en torso, ending in red hands. He is finishing washing, and now examines the pan-bottom: He washes the pan, plants one stalk of straw, goes downst Now, nothing. He clamps his hands on his knees and rises. He looks up t  45.

The trapper is rising out of a hole—which is waist-deep, climb the hill. At the river he washes the pan. The end result: the pan-b specks among the black, too many to count.

dialogues.text: Heh! Almost enough to keep! He plunges the pan into the stream and waggles it, washin He rises, stiff now. He looks up at the canyon rim. There is radiance dying at sun has disappeared. Evening breeze is stirring the trees

dialogues.text: All right! I’m gonna getcha. Not today, but I’m gonna getcha. You can’t run away Mr. Pocket!  46. As he goes down to his pack horse:

dialogues.text: The trapper has built a campfire. He sits before it eatin His chewing freezes for a beat as he stares into the fire chewing again, chuckling.

dialogues.speaker: LATER
dialogues.text: He finishes wrapping himself in a bedroll. A loud exhalation, a quiet beat. Then, sudden and loud:

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: Good night, Mr. Pocket! Chuckles, then he rolls over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By the hill the remains of fire, the man small. Faint chu

dialogues.speaker: MAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: ... Ahh me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The prospector stands in the middle of the stream, the le rolled up to the height of the water. He jerks on a length of string and pulls up a small silve sunlight. Looking up at the ridge above him he notices the owl alig

dialogues.speaker: THE PINE
dialogues.text: As the prospector, now fully dressed, inches his way up t and smaller limbs as he approaches the top. He has a burl  47. Ata flapping sound he looks up. In low angle we see the owl, disturbed by his approach, a Back to the prospector, hair stirred by breeze. A distant his hand to shadow his eyes. The horizon. Mountain after mountain softening with dista stirs. He looks down. An unfamiliar, high perspective on his hidden canyon. The its bank. The distant sound of the stream. He resumes climbing.

dialogues.speaker: AT THE NEST
dialogues.text: The prospector arrives. Five speckled eggs, barely bigger The prospector is carefully loading them one by one in hi something catches his look, arrests his egg-loading motio The displaced owl is perched on a tree maybe fifty yards him. The prospector looks at the owl, hand still arrested hold The owl looks at him. The prospector relents: he places the egg he holds not in next to the lone egg he had not yet taken. He mutters:

dialogues.speaker: PROSPECTOR
dialogues.text: Icain’t do it! He unloads the eggs already in his sling. PROSPECTOR (CONT’D) .. Damny. He considers. PROSPECTOR (CONT’D) Mebbe just one. He restores one egg to his sling and starts his descent.  48. PROSPECTOR (CONT’D) ... How high can a bird count, anyway...

dialogues.speaker: FRYING EGG
dialogues.text: An egg and a small fish sizzle in the frying pan.

dialogues.speaker: THE PROSPECTOR
dialogues.text: Eating, staring fixedly off as he chews. His point-of-view: the line of holes at the riverbank. The prospector, still chewing.

dialogues.speaker: PROSPECTOR
dialogues.text: Yep... yep... He sets the plate aside, rising: PROSPECTOR (CONT’D) Ya ready, Mr. Pocket?

dialogues.speaker: MINUTES LATER
dialogues.text: He is in a hole further up the hill, a little more than h not yet defined fully to the top by the progressively sho He claws small nuggets from the earth now, wipes them and puts them in a sack.

dialogues.speaker: PROSPECTOR
dialogues.text: Keepers now... gettin to keepers...

dialogues.speaker: LATER
dialogues.text: The sun is high. The prospector climbs from a hole sweating, shirt off, fu nuggets half-full.

dialogues.speaker: PROSPECTOR
dialogues.text: Lumps’n chunks... lumps’n chunks... He steps back, looks at the shape of his bendy, not-yet-f  49. He drops the sack, picks up the spade that is planted by hill referring to the downhill holes. A look back and forth and then he decisively plants the s presumptive apex of the triangle. PROSPECTOR (CONT’D) ... Right here! I got the almighty cinch on you, Mr. Pocket! You’re settin down there a-waitin for me! He picks up a canteen, tips his head back and pours water He blinks up at the hot sun. PROSPECTOR (CONT’D) .. Hold on sun, hold on. ’'m almost there.

dialogues.speaker: LATER
dialogues.text: The prospector is almost neck-deep in a hole about five f the sun, closer now to the western ridge. He gets down on his knees and claws through the dirt at t Nothing but dirt and rocks. Standing again he works on th it so he can swing a pick.

dialogues.speaker: LATER STILL
dialogues.text: The sun is lower. We see only the tip of the pick as it s at the apex of its arc. The hole is about eight feet deep steep angle.

dialogues.speaker: INSIDE THE HOLE
dialogues.text: As the pick bites into the soft earth. It strikes somethi spade and starts frantically shoveling the earth and toss and sinks to his knees and starts pawing at the dirt. A c He swipes it clean: it is half rotten quartz, half virgin

dialogues.speaker: PROSPECTOR
dialogues.text: Mother Machree!  50. The quartz/gold seam comes apart with just a little twist Still on his knees he tosses the huge gold chunk onto a b pit. He pulls another chunk from the pit wall in front of more of this one is gold. And another chunk. And another. PROSPECTOR (CONT’D) Hello Mr. Pocket! The pit, out of direct sunlight, is warmly lit by the lat raised by his digging and clawing. But now the light, ani dust, is subtly disturbed. The prospector freezes. What was it? Not a shadow. Was it wavered in the cloud of light and dust, is now still. We are very close on the prospector who faces into the pi not daring to turn his head. He thinks. After a long beat lump in front of him. More stillness. Not knowing what to do, not wanting to turn around, he st to brush dirt from the lump. When we cut from the lump to a close-up on his face it is an out-of-focus figure standing at the lip of the pit, ab The prospector clears his throat. He self-consciously whi nonchalance, tipping his head to admire the lump of gold. The soft silhouetted figure above is silently reaching so We cut to a high angle over the man’s shoulder, the prosp from us, on his knees, whistling. Motion in the body of t continuing and then completing the action of getting some is still. Back down to the prospector. We are now very close, his f prospector is beading sweat, looking at the lump, trying coming up with anything. His whistling dries. In the quie head. A loud roar and his body slams down out of frame. He hits the ground and is still. Renewed quiet.  51. The man looking down: a young man, almost a boy, clean-sh prospector, a six-gun smoking in his hand. He holds still his prey is dead. At length he relaxes, his gun no longer pointing but his the pit. The prospector’s limbs are in an awkward tangle. He has t corpse. Blood leaks from his back. The shooter slowly seats himself on the lip of the pit, l His eyes still on the corpse he sets the gun down and fis tobacco-sack from his pocket. He curls the paper, taps in curling the paper, licks it shut, lights it. As he inhales his look moves, for the first time, off the the stream and up the pines to where a shape moves: the o Evening breeze stirs the man’s hair. He gives a long exha into the pit. Seeped-out blood covers the back of the prospector’s shir The shooter, his look unemotive, sighs, licks forefinger against the end of the cigarette, killing it. He puts it picks up the gun. He braces both arms against the lip and drops himself int head as he lets go of the edge. Just as he lands the prospector, twisting with a wheezing shooter’s ankle and upsets his balance. The gun goes off side of the hole and filling it with smoke. Collapsing at the bottom the shooter tries to lower the g wrenched to the side as the gun goes off again. The two m space a riot of flailing limbs. The prospector does not l even as he lowers the gun to shoot. Suddenly the prospector throws a handful of dirt into the the gun away. The shooter raises his other hand in front of his face to the gun roars again, the bullet passing through his hand  52. The prospector struggles wheezing to his feet, dischargin into the young man’s body. The gunsmoke rises and the last gunshot rings out to leav looking down at the dead man covered in blood. Blood drip well, draining down the arm holding the gun still pointin PROSPECTOR (CONT’D) Ya measly skunk! A-campin on my trail and lettin me do the work an then shootin me in the back! He kicks at the dead man’s foot. PROSPECTOR (CONT’D)

dialogues.speaker: .. IN THE BACK
dialogues.text: Sobbing and moaning, he crawls out of the pit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He claws his shirt off as he staggers downhill to the str

dialogues.speaker: PROSPECTOR
dialogues.text: ... Ya measly SKUNK! He drops the gun at the riverbank and plows into the wate knee-bends to clear the blood so as to be able to examine He moans with pain and effort with each bob as he sloshes The exposed wound is in his midriff, to one side. He rais at the exit wound in his back. PROSPECTOR (CONT’D) ... Went clean through. Didn’t hit nothing important. Just guts! JUST

dialogues.speaker: GUTS, YA MEASLY SKUNK
dialogues.text: The shout is directed up the hill. The prospector reverts slaps water, cleaning the wound. He staggers out of the stream and goes to his little camp a bag, yelling uphill:  53. PROSPECTOR (CONT’D) ... Don’t worry, Mr. Pocket, I'll come back! He rips a length of cloth and we cut on the rip.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Early light. The holes. The dead shooter, caked with dirt and blood, lies at the been dragged out. On the other side of the pit uncleaned bag. Wheezing is audible within the pit. The prospector, now bandaged, is inside. The pit’s uphill pocket of gold having been clawed out. The prospector run surface, looking, pulling out a clod, satisfying himself

dialogues.speaker: PROSPECTOR
dialogues.text: Okay... okay... He emerges from the pit. He plants a toe under the corpse and, with one hand clamp keep it compressed while he strains, he rolls the dead ma PROSPECTOR (CONT’D) ... That’s yer share, ya measly skunk!

dialogues.speaker: THE LOADED HORSE
dialogues.text: Clanking and jangling with pots and pans. It is now also burlap sacks.

dialogues.speaker: PROSPECTOR
dialogues.text: There’s a spot in me heart Which nobody may own There’s a depth in my soul Never sounded or known... The prospector is leading the horse through the downhill  54. PROSPECTOR (CONT’D) There’s a place in my mem’ry —My heart—that you fill No other can take it No one ever will... His singing voice fades as the shrubs and branches close descent unseen. High: the owl’s point-of-view of the canyon. The burbling marred by the strange geometry of gouged holes. The distant voice fades to nothing. The sounds of the can

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Myr. Arthur had no idea what he would say to Billy Knapp

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 55- As we dissolve to a new title page we hear the sound of d The Gal Who Got Rattled he page turns to a new illustration: wide on a rolling pr

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: line of conestoga wagons recedes into the distance; a lon wagon train is about to meet a man on foot, his back to u his shoulder. He is trailed by a small black terrier. We move down to the caption at the bottom of the picture: Mr. Arthur had no idea what he would say to Billy Knapp. We dissolve to: INT. BOARDERS’ DINING ROOM - NIGHT

dialogues.speaker: A YAPPING DOG
dialogues.text: A little terrier wanders beneath a long table, among the nine or ten diners. A male hand reaches under the table with a scrap. The dog

dialogues.speaker: VOICE
dialogues.text: His cough did not respond to any kind of syrup or elixir... At the table: a half-dozen boarders among whom are Gilber Gilbert is just withdrawing his hand from under the table The speaker is a young salesman.

dialogues.speaker: SALESMAN
dialogues.text: I bought him every kind of remedy, out of my own pocket. Nothing palliated. Although one of them he drank avidly. And it was an extremely rattly cough. No, I was not sad to see Mr. Kincaid leave.

dialogues.speaker: LANDLADY
dialogues.text: It was not a contagious cough. Nobody here became ill. It was a nervous cough. I would not rent to a contagious cougher.  56.

dialogues.speaker: SALESMAN
dialogues.text: T have never heard of a nervous cough. (turns to Mrs. Longabaugh) T understand you are about to leave us.

dialogues.speaker: LANDLADY
dialogues.text: There is no medical affliction but that doesn’t have a nervous variety. The nervous system spreads its tendrils throughout the body. I saw a picture of it in a book.

dialogues.speaker: SALESMAN
dialogues.text: The nervous system does not have “tendrils.”

dialogues.speaker: LANDLADY
dialogues.text: I don’t pretend to be a physician, or a botanist. I know that the nervous system extends through the body and I presume that that is how it learns of the various physical conditions that it imitates.

dialogues.speaker: ANOTHER MAN
dialogues.text: Mrs. Flannery is quite right, I have seen that picture.

dialogues.speaker: LANDLADY
dialogues.text: My point is only that Mr. Kincaid was not a contagious cougher. I don’t rent to such.

dialogues.speaker: MIDDLE-AGED WOMAN
dialogues.text: Is there any more chicken and dumplings? The bowl came to me last.

dialogues.speaker: LANDLADY
dialogues.text: Yes there is more! We don’t stint at this table. Grandma Turner looks to be finished. Are you finished Grandma Turner! An old lady stares off, her mouth open.  57- The landlady nods. LANDLADY (CONT’D) ... Grandma Turner is finished.

dialogues.speaker: SALESMAN
dialogues.text: (to Alice) Leaving tomorrow? Jumping off the map, so to speak?

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Yes indeed, my brother and I are setting offin the morning, for Oregon.

dialogues.speaker: SALESMAN
dialogues.text: Oregon! You have people there, or a—

dialogues.speaker: LANDLADY
dialogues.text: Just scoop from her plate, Mrs. Halliday. Grandma Turner is quite done.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: No, I, not exactly—that is, my brother does.

dialogues.speaker: GILBERT
dialogues.text: Well go ahead and tell him Alice, don’t be tongue-tied. She has exciting news.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: I’m... I’m to be married. Or at least I may be, to Gilbert’s... associate.

dialogues.speaker: GILBERT
dialogues.text: He’s well fixed out there. The salesman can’t quite make out the situation. He looks

dialogues.speaker: SALESMAN
dialogues.text: You’re not certain whether you’re going to be married? Has the gentleman not proposed?

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Well, he— Alice looks up with embarrassment.

dialogues.speaker: GILBERT
dialogues.text: He will propose. Once they meet each other I’m sure Alice will pass muster. The match is a good one. Tm joining him in a business opportunity. And he’s declared himself ready to marry when he finds a suitable match. Alice can be very sociable and attractive when she has a mind to be. She doesn’t always have a mind to be.

dialogues.speaker: LANDLADY
dialogues.text: T think she is just the picture of charm and we will be so very sorry to see you go, Miss Longabaugh, you and Mr. Longabaugh both. And of course Mr. Longabaugh’s dog, little President Pierce, bless him. Where is he now?

dialogues.speaker: DAYS LATER
dialogues.text: We hear the steady yapping of a small dog but we are clos lead the ox; it is looking past us with watery, sad brown Reverse: the wagon ahead. The terrier stands inside with tailgate, looking out the back, steadily yapping. We can furiously wagging. It is keeping steady eye-contact with Alice trudges before the wagon in which the dog yaps. She Gilbert walks slightly ahead. Ahead of both a young man, their team of oxen. After a long beat walking:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gilbert.

dialogues.speaker: GILBERT
dialogues.text: Yes, sister. The dog is still yapping, and indeed yaps throughout. Alice is hesitant:

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Two people have asked me about President Pierce.

dialogues.speaker: GILBERT
dialogues.text: Asked?

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Well... complained.

dialogues.speaker: GILBERT
dialogues.text: About what?

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: The barking.

dialogues.speaker: GILBERT
dialogues.text: Indeed. Why to you?

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: I believe they assumed he was my dog.

dialogues.speaker: GILBERT
dialogues.text: Well I don’t know what to say. President Pierce is a nervous creature, and excited by animals larger than himself.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Almost all animals are larger than President Pierce.

dialogues.speaker: GILBERT
dialogues.text: (nettled) Well what of it?

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: People are... wondering if he will bark all the way to the Willamette Valley. 59.  60.

dialogues.speaker: GILBERT
dialogues.text: What if he does? There are property rights. The dog is my property. My property barks. There you have it. They walk in silence. Then: GILBERT (CONT’D) What did you tell them?

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: ... Well. Not that.

dialogues.speaker: GILBERT
dialogues.text: Yes, I can only imagine what you said. Alice: sometimes you have to tell people what’s what. Gilbert raises his hand and coughs into it, probably from

dialogues.speaker: DAYS LATER
dialogues.text: Night. On the prairie. Alice sits on the ground against a wagon wheel, in distre her hands clamp either side of her head. She is hypervent The little dog is near her, yapping up toward the wagon. From inside the wagon, moans building to a scream of agon The scream is succeeded by heavy breathing and then a ras

dialogues.speaker: GILBERT
dialogues.text: Alice! Staring at the ground she shakes her head, still hyperven She looks up. Peeking out over the tailgate of the next wagon in the ci at her. GILBERT (CONT’D) Alice!  61.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gilbert lies inside the wagon gazing upward, dead. Alice stares down at him. Early sunlight is diffused by the wagon’s canvas skin.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE
dialogues.text: Ma’am... Um, Miss... condolences... A man nearing sixty, mounted, looks in over the tailgate. two trailbosses. He is uncomfortable:

dialogues.speaker: MR. ARTHUR
dialogues.text: Condolences—goin back? Alice stares at him. It is as if she has not heard. Her m Mr. Arthur grows only more uncomfortable under her stare.

dialogues.speaker: MR. ARTHUR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: ... You, uh, goin back now, er... As we hear approaching hoofbeats Mr. Arthur’s panicked lo approaching rider, appealing for help.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY KNAPP
dialogues.text: Did you lose him? She stares at Billy Knapp. Gathering that she is not read BILLY KNAPP (CONT’D) Tam so very sorry. I will get a spade. She finds her voice:

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Yesterday morning he was fine.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY KNAPP
dialogues.text: It is very quick, cholera. Mr. Arthur has withdrawn a half-length behind Billy Knapp

dialogues.speaker: MR. ARTHUR
dialogues.text: She a go-backer?

dialogues.speaker: BILLY KNAPP
dialogues.text: Will you be goin back, Miss? Or pressin on?  62. She stares at him. He waits, and then a gentle prod: BILLY KNAPP (CONT’D) ... Goin back, or, stayin with the train?

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Goin back where?

dialogues.speaker: BILLY KNAPP
dialogues.text: Uh...

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: I... don’t have people.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY KNAPP
dialogues.text: Anyone ahead? In Oregon?

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: ... There is a gentleman... but I have not met him. I know his name.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY KNAPP
dialogues.text: Well... Pll get a spade.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billy Knapp is walloping the ground with the flat of a sh colleague Mr. Arthur watches from his horse, arms draped Billy Knapp notices Alice approaching and in deference st presses at the ground with his toe. She draws up, looking at the patch of earth.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY KNAPP
dialogues.text: Don’t want him dug up. Uh... you want a marker of any kind, or... She is staring at the ground. She looks up at him. No ans BILLY KNAPP (CONT’D) Well. We'll leave it at that. Better anyway not to advertise to the Indians. They will scavenge. She looks at him with alarm, which he notes.  BILLY KNAPP (CONT'D) 3. ... They don’t bother us, none. Too much trouble attackin a wagon train, too little reward. You got a hired boy don’t you Miss Longabaugh?

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Yes. Matt.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY KNAPP
dialogues.text: ‘N he'll handle the team.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: He has been. Gilbert did very little.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY KNAPP
dialogues.text: Very well. You call upon myself or Mr. Arthur ifyou... She looks from one man to the other. Mr. Arthur says nothing. He turns his horse and rides awa EXT. TRAILBOSS’ COOKFIRE - NIGHT Two men sit at a campfire: facing us, Mr. Arthur, and fac just lifting a brand from the fire to light himself a cig quiet, comfortable enough with each other to not talk. When Mr. Arthur sees Alice walking up he catches Billy’s Billy Knapp follows.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY KNAPP
dialogues.text: Miss.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Please, sit down. Could I ask your advice, Mr. Knapp?

dialogues.speaker: BILLY KNAPP
dialogues.text: Certainly, miss. Will you have a coffee with us?

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: No thank you. My hired boy, Matt. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ALICE (CONT’D) He told me that my brother promised him half his wages when we get to Fort Laramie.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY KNAPP
dialogues.text: Yes miss?

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Well...

dialogues.speaker: BILLY KNAPP
dialogues.text: What’d he say that was?

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Two hundred dollars.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY KNAPP
dialogues.text: Two hundred dollars is half?

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Yes. And the other half when we get to the Willamette Valley. Billy Knapp and Mr. Arthur exchange a look.

dialogues.speaker: MR. ARTHUR
dialogues.text: A high price. These words—the first we’ve heard Mr. Arthur speak—have b in particular. Billy Knapp addresses Alice:

dialogues.speaker: BILLY KNAPP
dialogues.text: It is an extravagant wage.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Is it?

dialogues.speaker: MR. ARTHUR
dialogues.text: That’s a high price.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY KNAPP
dialogues.text: Do you think the boy is telling a story? Now that your brother is no longer...

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: I don’t know. The two men again look at each other.  65. ALICE (CONT’D) ... Gilbert was not a good business person. He had an enterprise in Towa City, that ended poorly... And earlier, another that... There is no judgment in the question:

dialogues.speaker: BILLY KNAPP
dialogues.text: He was a failure?

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: I suppose.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY KNAPP
dialogues.text: Still, the boy...

dialogues.speaker: MR. ARTHUR
dialogues.text: That’s a high price.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Well. There is another problem. I... I cannot find any money in the wagon. I believe Gilbert kept it in his waistcoat. Again, the two men look at each other.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY KNAPP
dialogues.text: Then he’s still got it.

dialogues.speaker: MR. ARTHUR
dialogues.text: One day’s ride.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY KNAPP
dialogues.text: Yessir but, what, midday tomorrow, I smoothed it, kicked scrub over it’n who knows what passed in the night. No, I don’t think so. No. He turns back to Alice. He thinks. At length: BILLY KNAPP (CONT’D) ... I suggest you not argue with the boy til we get to Fort Laramie.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: And then? Quiet.  66.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY KNAPP
dialogues.text: Well, maybe I will talk to the boy, see if I can shake him loose from his story. Four hundred dollars. I don’t know. I will have to think on this one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We hear dog yapping. We are looking at the back of a young man in a battered f leading a team of oxen. He looks over his shoulder. He is an unprepossessing youn Behind him: Alice. She does not react to the boy’s sullen EXT. ALICE’S COOKFIRE - EVENING Alice and the young man are eating wordlessly at their co Intermittent yaps from the dog. Billy Knapp walks up.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY KNAPP
dialogues.text: Miss, could I have a word?

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Certainly Mr. Knapp, can I offer you supper?

dialogues.speaker: BILLY KNAPP
dialogues.text: Thank you, miss, I have had mine.

dialogues.speaker: I
dialogues.text: The young man, having given Billy Knapp a hostile look on leaves with his plate of food. Billy Knapp watches him go BILLY KNAPP (CONT’D) This is awkward miss, but people have complained to Mr. Arthur and myself about your little, uh, President Pierce. I have no doubt but that your dog is—  67.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: He is not my dog.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY KNAPP
dialogues.text: w.. Miss?

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: He was—Mr. Longabaugh’s. I know it’s terrible, the noise. I don’t know what to do.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY KNAPP
dialogues.text: Isee. I see. Well then—I thought he was your dog—maybe this is quite a simple matter, uh... could I put him down for you, miss?

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: All right. Well. Could we not just scare him off?

dialogues.speaker: BILLY KNAPP
dialogues.text: Well no, we are his food so he will try to follow, long as he can. And then—a wolf might play with him before he eats him. Faster is better.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Yes. I understand. Yes, thank you very much, if you would take care of it.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY KNAPP
dialogues.text: It will be no trouble at all, miss. I will attend to it right away.—Oh (lowered voice) T regret to have to tell you—I talked to your boy Matt. I could not get him to budge.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Well. Well. Thank you Mr. Knapp, you are very kind to extend yourself.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY KNAPP
dialogues.text: It is no trouble, miss. Here we go, little dog...  68. He stoops, coaxing the terrier in with an extended hand. BILLY KNAPP (CONT’D) ... All right, miss. He touches his hat and walks away, dog in the crook of hi toward a nearby rise. Alice watches the spot he left. She rouses herself, takes another bite of food. No appetite. She sets the plate down. She reseats herself leaning against a wagon wheel. She dr hands up to cover her ears. A long wait. A pop/ She flinches. She slowly lowers her hands. She starts to rise, and then: Pop! She is puzzled. Then, two more in quick succession: pop/ pop! She goes around the wagon, looks out. The nearby rise. After a beat, Billy Knapp appears. He walks toward her, g sheepish. When he arrives: BILLY KNAPP (CONT’D) I set President Pierce down and he moved just as I fired. He skittered off, miss—I don’t believe I hit him a’tall.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Oh. Oh my.  69.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY KNAPP
dialogues.text: Tam truly sorry, miss, I should have deputized Mr. Arthur. That man is a crack shot. I did not expect it tO... tO...

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Well. It was very kind of you.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY KNAPP
dialogues.text: I do not think you will see President Pierce again...

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Yes. Yes, thank you Mr. Knapp.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Trudging. Alice somewhat behind, the sullen youth leading EXT. TRAILBOSS’ COOKFIRE #2 - NIGHT Mr. Arthur and Billy Knapp are at their cookfire. Billy K a cup, takes a last sip and tosses the dregs. He takes a pocket and bites offa chaw. Nearby Mr. Arthur turns his empty cup upside down and tap Billy Knapp hands him the plug.

dialogues.speaker: MR. ARTHUR
dialogues.text: Obliged. He looks up at the sound of footsteps. Alice approaching. his feet. Mr. Arthur remains sitting.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: I’m, I’m sorry to trouble you again. There’s no need to—

dialogues.speaker: BILLY KNAPP
dialogues.text: You are no trouble, Miss Longabaugh.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: I do apologize, Mr. Knapp, interrupting your supper. Mr. Arthur has risen to his feet. He walks off towards th  She does. 70.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY KNAPP
dialogues.text: Miss, please set your mind at ease. Thave hired on as trailboss and it is my duty to guide the train and meet square any unexpected problem. You have full call on my services.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Well I am grateful whether it is your duty or not. But things are developing for the worse. Matt—my boy—

dialogues.speaker: BILLY KNAPP
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Matt has asked me to affirm his arrangement with my brother. He asks me to declare that he will receive his two payments—at Fort Laramie, and in Oregon. He says if I will not affirm it, he will depart. He will join the first party of go-backers we meet.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY KNAPP
dialogues.text: And leave you. Leave you here with the wagon, high and dry.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY KNAPP
dialogues.text: Well well well. The impertinence.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Yes, but...

dialogues.speaker: BILLY KNAPP
dialogues.text: Please set down miss. We had better talk about this.  71.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: I don’t like it. But I don’t know that it is wrong of him to ask. He is doing a job, for pay.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY KNAPP
dialogues.text: Well. You are very broadminded, to see the other side of it.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: But then what shall I do, Mr. Knapp? Shall I confess I have no money? What is right?

dialogues.speaker: BILLY KNAPP
dialogues.text: What is right. He nods. They both stare into the fire. Billy Knapp finally stirs. BILLY KNAPP (CONT’D) Miss Longabaugh. I cannot offer to drive your team or tend your wagon in place of the boy. Mr. Arthur—

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: I would not ask you to do so!

dialogues.speaker: BILLY KNAPP
dialogues.text: Indeed, these are my thoughts not yours. Mr. Arthur and I have to ride one in front of the train, one behind, we take turns pilot and drag. But... Will you trust me for a day?

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Well. Certainly. But how so?

dialogues.speaker: BILLY KNAPP
dialogues.text: Tell the boy that you affirm the agreement. I want to think on this for a day. I have a notion that you may think is crackpot, but I do not believe it is.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Tm sure it is not crackpot.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY KNAPP
dialogues.text: Well we'll see. Give me a day. I must talk to Mr. Arthur. Then we will talk tomorrow, and if you think it is a bad idea, why, then, we will only have taken one extra day of the boy’s labor. Mr. Arthur rides in the dust haze at the back of the wago lower face and hat brim pulled low as protection against wagons he trails. Billy Knapp trots oncoming and wheels around to ride with bandana up. A beat of silent riding. Then, with jollity: Another beat. The shortest beat.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY KNAPP
dialogues.text: Afternoon, pardner.

dialogues.speaker: MR. ARTHUR
dialogues.text: Afternoon.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY KNAPP
dialogues.text: Which is worse, pardner, dust or mud?

dialogues.speaker: MR. ARTHUR
dialogues.text: Both I guess.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY KNAPP
dialogues.text: .. Say, I am thinking of proposing to Miss Longabaugh.

dialogues.speaker: MR. ARTHUR
dialogues.text: That right.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY KNAPP
dialogues.text: Yes, and if she accepts, well then, I plan to settle in Oregon. This would be my last wagon train...  73+ Another beat. BILLY KNAPP (CONT’D) ... I will farm.

dialogues.speaker: MR. ARTHUR
dialogues.text: Uh-huh.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY KNAPP
dialogues.text: Well. We'll see how she takes it. Mr. Arthur says nothing. BILLY KNAPP (CONT’D) ... Well, I will head back up. Unless you desire a swap.

dialogues.speaker: MR. ARTHUR
dialogues.text: Nope.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY KNAPP
dialogues.text: ... Afternoon.

dialogues.speaker: MR. ARTHUR
dialogues.text: Afternoon. Billy Knapp gallops off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is night and two fiddlers play for a gathering within among the people watching those who dance. Billy Knapp en

dialogues.speaker: BILLY KNAPP
dialogues.text: Miss.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Good evening Mr. Knapp. As he joins her she turns back to the dancing, and both s

dialogues.speaker: BILLY KNAPP
dialogues.text: May we talk for a moment?

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Yes, of course. The two amble to get a little distance from the noise. ALICE (CONT’D) So. Your crackpot notion.  74.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY KNAPP
dialogues.text: Yes. Yes. Before I expose it—may I ask something?

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Certainly.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY KNAPP
dialogues.text: What... possibilities do you look forward to in Oregon? She slows and they find themselves stopping at a tilted-u on it and, as she considers her answer, Billy plants one forearms over his knees.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: I don’t quite know. Gilbert knows—knew—someone there, a Mr. Vereen, who owns an orchard, or maybe more than one orchard, and a cartage company. He was vague about his connection with Mr. Vereen and, and about his own prospective position. I don’t wish to slight my brother’s memory, but, he could... exaggerate the nature of an opportunity. As I have told you, he had little aptitude for business. And Mr. Vereen’s interest in... myself—I fear that may also have been speculative...

dialogues.speaker: BILLY KNAPP
dialogues.text: Isee. I see. So this is no definite prospect of marriage, no contract.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: I—no.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY KNAPP
dialogues.text: Well my idea then is this. And I submit it in respect, Miss Longabaugh. I propose to assume your brother’s debt to the hired boy, and to... to ask you to marry me.  75+

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Oh!

dialogues.speaker: BILLY KNAPP
dialogues.text: I submit it in respect.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Oh! Oh.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY KNAPP
dialogues.text: I... my notion is to farm in the Willamette.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: ... I don’t know what to say.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY KNAPP
dialogues.text: T have ambushed you, I am very sorry.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: No, no.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY KNAPP
dialogues.text: I should clarify what brings me to say these things or I will seem like the veriest bounder. I have found myself thinking about certain matters, um. I have been bustin trail for fifteen years, the last twelve with Mr. Arthur. Mr. Arthur is a top man. Top man. But he is getting older, and... slower to straighten in the morning. Sleeping on the ground, miss, to have no family and to sleep on the ground.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Yes. Yes. It cannot be easy.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY KNAPP
dialogues.text: Yes, looking at him, well... I myself have come to the age where, either I will settle, and have children who can take care of me when I am old. Or I will not. That time will have passed.  76.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY KNAPP
dialogues.text: So I have found myself thinking, well, if I met a, a maiden, or a widow of honor, uh, perhaps I would...

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY KNAPP
dialogues.text: Present myself...

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Yes, I see.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY KNAPP
dialogues.text: Uh... They both gaze into the fire, the most neutral place to l At length, but still looking in the fire: BILLY KNAPP (CONT’D) You’re acquainted with the 1872 Grant? Alice looks at him.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Tam not. He is still looking in the fire.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY KNAPP
dialogues.text: Settler in Oregon can claim 320 acres. Married couple can claim 640. There is a, um... In Fort Laramie there is a Mr. Bourgeois who can sanctify marriage. After some thought.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Do you engage in divine worship. Now he looks at her, finding relief in a matter-of-fact q

dialogues.speaker: BILLY KNAPP
dialogues.text: Yes, Iam a Methodist. Yourself, miss?

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Tam Episcopalian. Again they lapse into a silence, but not a troubled one. impediment. Then:

dialogues.speaker: ALICE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What is your... Christian name, Mr. Knapp?

dialogues.speaker: BILLY KNAPP
dialogues.text: William. I am Billy Knapp.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Tam Alice Longabaugh. He nods. Alice looks into the fire.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Well... now I suppose it is my turn to think. He rises.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY KNAPP
dialogues.text: Of course. We will um... We will let the boy keep working for the moment? On his assumption of payment? Alice looks at him, draws breath to answer, but stops, fr Billy Knapp looks at her, trying to read her look, wonder dismayed by it. Then he too frowns. We begin to hear it: a distant yapping. It fades, grows, and forth across the border of audibility.  78.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On another wagon: a woman rides on the jockey box with a Two bigger children, boys, walk in front of the wagon. On backwards. The other is laughing.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: What are you doing, Israel?

dialogues.speaker: BOY
dialogues.text: Walking backwards. Gonna walk the rest of the way to Oregon backwards.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: Don’t do that.

dialogues.speaker: BOY
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: I said don’t do that. The father, walking by the oxen with a switch, turns and

dialogues.speaker: FATHER
dialogues.text: Don’t do that. The boy stumbles round, surprised and smarting. The fathe with a dark:

dialogues.speaker: FATHER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: ... Listen to yer mother.

dialogues.speaker: HEAD OF THE WAGON TRAIN
dialogues.text: Today Mr. Arthur is in the fresh-aired vanguard. He draws his horse to a halt at the brink of a gentle dec cottonwoods. He looks side to side, assessing. Mr. Arthur gives a look up at the sun, considers. He reins his horse around and backtracks to meet the appr up one hand.

dialogues.speaker: MR. ARTHUR
dialogues.text: Noon here.  79.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The chunking of wagon wheels has stopped at the cut, repl people preparing food and chatting and tending to chores. Billy Knapp descends toward the stream, dusty and sweatin Reverse on Mr. Arthur, sitting before a cookfire and eati down to eat by the stream, or to wash things in it, or-—c Mr. Arthur’s back is to us. Responding to the sound of Bi glances back over his shoulder. As Billy Knapp draws up a a plate of dinner.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY KNAPP
dialogues.text: Thank you. The two men eat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The train has resumed; Alice trudges behind her wagon.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE
dialogues.text: Miss, uh... She looks around. Billy Knapp, mounted, is trotting up fr

dialogues.speaker: BILLY KNAPP
dialogues.text: I thought I should add, miss, to my proposal?

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: You may call me Alice. Billy dismounts and leads his horse to walk alongside her

dialogues.speaker: BILLY KNAPP
dialogues.text: I thought I should add, Alice—lest I seem hard-nosed—f you see fit to decline my proposal, why, there is more than one way to skin a cat. We might find a boy from another wagon to drive your team, use your oxen as payment in Oregon. Someone might be willing. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILLY KNAPP (CONT’D) Or distribute your necessities among other wagons. We will get you to Oregon, safe and sound, I don’t wish to present myself as the only alternative to ruination. It would be wrong to take advantage.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: The thought does you credit, William. But I’m inclined to accept your proposal.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY KNAPP
dialogues.text: All right. All right.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: I didn’t take your offer to be opportunism and I don’t take yourself to be hard-nosed.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY KNAPP
dialogues.text: That puts my mind at ease, I am glad to hear it.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: My dear brother was very hard-nosed. But never very successful. Those two things, in combination—it made life a frustration for him.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY KNAPP
dialogues.text: I see how it would. You feel badly for him.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: I do. Now. More than I did. Other people didn’t care for him. He had only me. And I had only him.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY KNAPP
dialogues.text: Tam very sorry that you have lost him. But he is with his creator. His way is easy now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, of course. Yes, his way was difficult. I must say, it was difficult to be with him, he never found calm and he never gave calm. I was very nervous being with him. Not afraid of him—he would not hurt a fly—I was just—not at ease. I was eaten up by nerves at the thought of talking to Mr. Vereen for instance. The thought of meeting him was an agony. I don’t know how I would have done it. And yet you are so very easy to talk to.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY KNAPP
dialogues.text: Perhaps we'll find comfort together, spiritual ease—that was my hope as well. Alice.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Yes. William.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billy Knapp is bent low, hobbling his horse. He speaks to

dialogues.speaker: BILLY KNAPP
dialogues.text: Well, it... it appears that Miss Longabaugh is inclined to accept my proposal, He straightens up. Mr. Arthur has unsaddled and hobbled h their pack mule, examining its load.

dialogues.speaker: MR. ARTHUR
dialogues.text: Uh huh.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY KNAPP
dialogues.text: Yes, it uh... Of course you will do fine, solo, no doubt about it, a man of your skills will always be in high demand. Mr. Arthur is picking through the pack.  82.

dialogues.speaker: MR. ARTHUR
dialogues.text: ... Wheres’at mecate rope?—Neb mind, here it is. EXT. ALICE’S COOKFIRE #2 - NIGHT Billy Knapp and Alice sit at Alice’s fire, both gazing in of coffee. A long beat.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: ... When will we see buffalo?

dialogues.speaker: BILLY KNAPP
dialogues.text: Oh soon, very soon. Another beat. Billy Knapp’s musings are directed at the f BILLY KNAPP (CONT’D) ... Used to hunt the big shaggies, provisioned for the army. Did some trapping. Years. Found myself missing animals’t walked upright. Started piloting. Partnered up with Mr. Arthur.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: What did Mr. Arthur do, previously? Billy Knapp thinks, realizes:

dialogues.speaker: BILLY KNAPP
dialogues.text: Don’t know... More fire-gazing. BILLY KNAPP (CONT’D) ... That man is a wonder. He can read the prairie like a book. To see him cut for sign, well—you’d think the good lord dealt us each our five senses, then bottom-dealt Mr. Arthur one extra. Still... he is old. I don’t know how it will go with him. His affairs may... I can’t help feeling in the wrong.  Quiet. 83.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Your first responsibility is to your household.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY KNAPP
dialogues.text: Yes, but...

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: T’m sorry. I should not dismiss it with an easy apothegm.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY KNAPP
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Gilbert had a saying for any situation. A ready bit of wisdom. He was very certain.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY KNAPP
dialogues.text: He was a doughface?

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: How did—oh, yes. He was an admirer of President Pierce, yes, very much so. He had fixed political beliefs. All of his beliefs were quite fixed, even those that... fortune did not tend to endorse. He would upbraid me for being “wishy-washy.” I never had his certainties. I suppose it’s a defect.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY KNAPP
dialogues.text: Oh, I don’t think it is a defect at all. Oh no. Uncertainty—that is appropriate for the matters of this world. Only regarding the next are we vouchsafed certainty.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Yes.  84.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY KNAPP
dialogues.text: I believe certainty regarding that which we see and touch—it is seldom justified, if ever. Down the ages, from our remote past, what certainties survive? And yet we hurry to fashion new ones. Wanting their comfort. (shakes his head) “Certainty”—it is the easy path, Just as you said. They are both looking into the fire.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Strait is the gate...

dialogues.speaker: BILLY KNAPP
dialogues.text: ... and narrow the way. Indeed. Indeed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Arthur sinks into a squat in close shot, looking down The soft ground in the streambed he has stopped at, shows Back to Mr. Arthur. His look swivels to his left, followi He slowly rises, his appraising look directed at the hori background—behind him—continues to advance toward us, its arrived. Mr. Arthur’s point-of-view shows a gentle rise but not mu horizon. Peaceful as can be. The man walking before the first wagon in the train is dr

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: Sign, Mr. Arthur?

dialogues.speaker: MR. ARTHUR
dialogues.text: Horses. (a gesture forward as he mounts up) Keep on. Gonna talk to Mr. Knapp.  85.

dialogues.speaker: MR. ARTHUR
dialogues.text: Ata canter, going down the line of wagons. A puzzled look as he draws even with the wagon led by Mat

dialogues.speaker: MR. ARTHUR
dialogues.text: Wharza woman?

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: Tsat? Mr. Arthur reins his horse around to walk abreast with Ma

dialogues.speaker: MR. ARTHUR
dialogues.text: Mrs. Longabaugh, wharshe?

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: Went o’er air. A vague wave to the left of the wagon train—the same perp hoofprints.

dialogues.speaker: MR. ARTHUR
dialogues.text: O’er air? Whyzat?

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: Huh. I’dno. Heard that mutt barkin’. Pres’dent Pierce. There is some concern now in Mr. Arthur’s look toward the

dialogues.speaker: MR. ARTHUR
dialogues.text: Whenshe go?

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: Wull. ’dno.

dialogues.speaker: MR. ARTHUR
dialogues.text: Whenshe go?! A shrug from Matt.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: Half ar.

dialogues.speaker: MR. ARTHUR
dialogues.text: Uh-hnghh.  86. A beat looking and he spurs his horse to the left.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Arthur is spurring and reining his horse in a forward intently down at the prairie grass just in front of him. background, several hundred yards behind Mr. Arthur now, to our eyes—unmarked prairie grass. Mr. Arthur abruptly tacks, taking the opposite-ways diago trained on the grass just before him. He stops the horse, His point of view, since he now has a bit of elevation, s prairie grass. No human yet visible. He spurs his horse forward.

dialogues.speaker: FURTHER ON
dialogues.text: Mr. Arthur tops a rise and reins his horse in to look dow Ms. Longabaugh is sitting on a small hillock holding a ya In front of her the earth is disturbed by a multitude of which, every now and then, pops the head of a prairie dog Mr. Arthur looks around from his high perspective then ge toward the woman.

dialogues.speaker: A MINUTE LATER
dialogues.text: Mr. Arthur arriving. Alice, smiling, sits on her horse ho by the little animals at which President Pierce barks. He she talks.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: What are they, Mr. Arthur?

dialogues.speaker: MR. ARTHUR
dialogues.text: Prairie dogs, ma’am. Uh, ma’am... We best, uh... She still watches the little animals, one or two of whom at President Pierce.  87.

dialogues.speaker: MR. ARTHUR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: ... Ma’am, there’s uh—

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Aren’t they darling?

dialogues.speaker: MR. ARTHUR
dialogues.text: Yes’m. We'd better—um, gittin late. She laughs.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: It’s hours till dark. Mr. Arthur’s look has latched onto something on the horiz ALICE (CONT’D) .. I believe President Pierce is trying to understand whether those creatures are other dogs, or— Mr. Arthur abruptly dismounts. He strides over to Alice’s

dialogues.speaker: MR. ARTHUR
dialogues.text: Git down.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
