dialogues.text: Why, Mr. Arthur— He pulls at her with an urgency that precludes resistance

dialogues.speaker: MR. ARTHUR
dialogues.text: Git down now, Miss. He has half-pulled her down but she has landed on her fee arms to yap at the prairie dogs. Alice is alarmed by his sudden change of attitude.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Mr. Arthur— He is not even looking at her: he is hobbling her horse.

dialogues.speaker: MR. ARTHUR
dialogues.text: Set below this rise here. He goes to hobble his own horse as she watches, bewildere  88.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: But—we’re not going back?

dialogues.speaker: MR. ARTHUR
dialogues.text: Not directly. A short gesture with his head. She looks—and gives a sobbing little cry. An Indian on horseback, motionless, silhouetted on the di Mr. Arthur rises from his horse and takes five strides ou hand out toward him head palm-forward. He stops, fixed in No motion from the Indian. Mr. Arthur returns:

dialogues.speaker: MR. ARTHUR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We're in for a fight. He won’t answer m’peace sign’n he’s a Sioux. (shakes his head) We can’t make a run for it through this dog-town. She is agitated but tries to calm herself with a thought:

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: There’s only one savage. Mr. Arthur laughs.

dialogues.speaker: MR. ARTHUR
dialogues.text: Keep lookin. Other Indians are joining the first, forming a facing lin them all told. Mr. Arthur is dragging the saddle off his hillock.

dialogues.speaker: MR. ARTHUR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: ... They'll crush us. Course, dog-holes as bad fer them as fer us, and they don’t know how to fight. He unscabards his Winchester and checks the breach, gets it, talking as he works:  89.

dialogues.speaker: MR. ARTHUR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: If they was to come in on all sides I couldn’t handle ‘em, but they rush in a bunch, like damn fools!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He chuckles—but then catches himself at the bad language.

dialogues.speaker: MR. ARTHUR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Beg pardon, Miss. Now you set there, take this. He is giving her the revolver. She will not reach for it; hand over the gun.

dialogues.speaker: MR. ARTHUR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Take’t now. Two bullets in it. She is starting to tremble.

dialogues.speaker: MR. ARTHUR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Don’t mean f’you to help me. You can’t help me, don’t even try, jus’ keep tucked low here below the crest. If I see we’re licked, PIL drop back’n shoot you and then shoot m’self, so that’s okay. But if you see that I’m done for, well, you'll have to do fer yourself... He puts a finger on her forehead.

dialogues.speaker: MR. ARTHUR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You put it right there so’s ya cain’t miss.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: No no—

dialogues.speaker: MR. ARTHUR
dialogues.text: This is business Miss Longabaugh. They ketch you well it won’t be so good. After they... take off ever stitch a yer clothes n’have their way with ye they’ll stretch you out with a rawhide to each of yer arms’n legs. Then they'll drive a (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: MR. ARTHUR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: stake through the middle of your body into the ground and then... do some other things. And we can’t have that. She is shaking. Now he reassures:

dialogues.speaker: MR. ARTHUR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We ain’t licked yet. But if we are, you know what to do. She vigorously nods.

dialogues.speaker: MR. ARTHUR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: ... That first injun there, he’s the mucky-muck’n if I shoot him well that’s bad medicine’n I think they'll all lose their spit’n light out. He chuckles again.

dialogues.speaker: MR. ARTHUR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: They’re a funny bunch. (starts down the bill to his saddle) Anyway, we’ll have a GOOD fight! He covers, making himself comfortable behind the saddle, The Indians have started to move, the center of their lin the ends moving toward the middle to fall into line behin abreast column. Mr. Arthur projects:

dialogues.speaker: MR. ARTHUR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: They'll start makin noise now, sposed to skeer us but it won’t bother us none will it Miss? She returns a rather tremulous—

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: No, Mr. Arthur. —as the whooping starts.  91. Crack!—the first rifle shot from one of the Indians. A co sighting but not firing.

dialogues.speaker: MR. ARTHUR
dialogues.text: Well that’s a waste a bullets. More gunfire from the Indians as the column starts to spl still advancing. We now hear the whistle of bullets going by close. Divots the saddle, spraying earth. Mr. Arthur does not react, but now he fires. A forward ho rider. Mr. Arthur tracks another rider as the incoming fire cont spills without his firing. He bellows:

dialogues.speaker: MR. ARTHUR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: ... Dog-hole! He swings to track another forward rider: the man with th He fires: a miss. More and more incoming bullets, nearby impacts. Alice’s h its hobbled legs awkwardly pawing air until it collapses, Mr. Arthur fires at a rider now at the forward-most part columns. The man is hit. He swings his gun to the rider on the mirroring side, fir down its rider leaps clear. The two columns have now peeled completely and are windin The Indian whose horse was shot is running forward though Arthur takes leisurely aim, and fires, ending his charge. The whoops of the other Indians continue but are fading, Mr. Arthur eases up from the saddle. He again takes caref The Indian struggling to his feet by the dog-holed horse, awkwardly, screaming. Mr. Arthur fires. The Indian is hit. Mr. Arthur relaxes.  92.

dialogues.speaker: MR. ARTHUR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Okay, they got the lay of the land. He reloads his gun, attention split between it and the In Their whoops have abated, but they are reforming on the r

dialogues.speaker: MR. ARTHUR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: ... This time they’ll come with a purpose. You all right Miss?

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Yes Mr. Arthur. He goes to Alice’s whimpering horse and shoots it in the horse taking out a knife, and with one slice severs its h sending it galloping off. The whooping is starting again as the Indians begin their walks unhurriedly back to his saddle-fort.

dialogues.speaker: MR. ARTHUR
dialogues.text: They ain’t gonna do it all day. This’ll tell the tale. This time he doesn’t bother with cover but remains standi Distant cracks of gunfire. Mr. Arthur is sighting at the man in headdress. A loud cr Nearer incoming fire. Mr. Arthur aims at the next man in line as the leader pul him, unridering the horse. The Indians do not display the formation of their first c they now seem to be everywhere, whooping. Crack!—Mr. Arthur hits another Indian who has drawn almos pans to aim at a rider passing on the other side. Crack!— He rises—

dialogues.speaker: MR. ARTHUR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Leave’m to me, Miss! —and fires and the Indian is shot off his horse. Crack—an incoming bullet flaps Mr. Arthur’s shirt.  93. He spins and quickly sights the incoming chief. He fires rifle lost. Mr. Arthur quickly fires again and the man is He is on the ground, not far away. Mr. Arthur advances on rifle at his hip, fires, hits him square in the chest. He raises his rifle looking for a new target. But the Ind away, scattering, leaving the field. Some of them fire at impotent gesture. Among the milling horses are three now riderless mounts j Arthur turns from the horses, targets a retreating Indian One of the loose horses is heading toward him from behind Mr. Arthur turns at the sound and lowers his rifle to app The horse, which looks like it will pass him wide, sudden up from its offside and in the same motion swings an arm Mr. Arthur is caught square on the head and falls back, l The rider pulls his horse up and vaults down before it ha sending him toward Mr. Arthur as he pulls a knife from hi As he reaches the inert body—Mr. Arthur’s right hand rise The Indian falls dead. Mr. Arthur woozily rises. He gazes out at the field. The last of the Indians are disappearing. The occasional Quiet returns. The only near sound is the rasping of a fa hole. Mr. Arthur turns back to the crest of the hill where Pres Near the dog is Alice, lying on her back, a bullet hole i Mr. Arthur comes up short, staring.

dialogues.speaker: MR. ARTHUR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Oh my. He stares. He shakes his head in deep distress.  94. MR. ARTHUR (CONT’D) Pore little gal. She hadn’t ought to have did it! He turns away stunned, the dog yapping at his feet.

dialogues.speaker: MR. ARTHUR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: .. Oh my. He walks woodenly away.

dialogues.speaker: MR. ARTHUR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: .. Oh my. An Indian by the rasping horse is struggling to his hands him offhandedly as he passes. Dissolve to:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In an endless sea of grass. Mr. Arthur crests the rise on foot, the Winchester slung yapping dog still following. Before him, in the distance, the wagon train lumbers away from the end of it to meet him, is Billy Knapp. Beyond the wagon train, the rolling prairie.

dialogues.speaker: FADE OUT
dialogues.text: FADE IN on the title of the last story:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whether or not he heard, the coachman did not slow.  95. The Mortal Remains e hear the rumble of wheels over gravel and dirt as we di

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: illustration. Looking steeply up the side of a stagecoach in full fligh against a twilight sky. He is dressed in a greatcoat, his face. The wind blows his scarf behind him as he cracks hi caption: Fe gave no sign that he had heard the Frenchman bellowing We hear someone humming, then singing to himself—merry bu Me Love Her All the More” as we dissolve to the inside of

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are looking in turn at the occupants of the coach: a d mustache and a neat string tie, gazing, bored, out the wi late middle-age, reading a small book with marbled pages her lips pursed. An elderly man with unruly white hair an mustache who is asleep, chin on chest, bouncing with the man in a too-tight suit. And finally the singer: a middle-aged man impeccably dres He finishes the verse with perhaps a bit too much energy: his head up and blinks and focuses. The singer, Nelson Thigpen, has a British accent:

dialogues.speaker: THIGPEN
dialogues.text: Oh, I am sorry. Didn’t mean to wake you, sir.

dialogues.speaker: TRAPPER
dialogues.text: (querulous) You did not wake me! He works his mouth, wets his lips, swallows. TRAPPER (CONT’D) .. For I was not asleep. Thigpen humors him:  96.

dialogues.speaker: THIGPEN
dialogues.text: Oh, not asleep, I see. He looks smilingly at the other occupants, and winks at t not be enlisted in derision: she looks dryly back to her Thigpen’s cheer is undimmed. THIGPEN (CONT’D) .. Well I apologize for disturbing anyone else. If I did. He looks around to no reaction. The invitation to convers trapper, who has been looking out the window, now wonders

dialogues.speaker: TRAPPER
dialogues.text: How much to go d’you reckon?

dialogues.speaker: THIGPEN
dialogues.text: Oh nota great distance, not great at all, we’re making good time. You haven’t been to Fort Morgan before, T take it.

dialogues.speaker: TRAPPER
dialogues.text: Me? No. You?

dialogues.speaker: THIGPEN
dialogues.text: Oh yes many times, many times. Ferrying cargo. A glance upward indicates the unseen cargo on the coach’s the glance.

dialogues.speaker: TRAPPER
dialogues.text: Him’s yourn?

dialogues.speaker: THIGPEN
dialogues.text: As much as he’s anyone’s, isn’t he, Clarence. The burly man nods.

dialogues.speaker: LADY
dialogues.text: A loved one?

dialogues.speaker: THIGPEN
dialogues.text: (wisele) By somebody, perhaps!  97.

dialogues.speaker: FRENCHMAN
dialogues.text: You did not know heem?

dialogues.speaker: THIGPEN
dialogues.text: (wise) We knew him only at the end.

dialogues.speaker: CLARENCE
dialogues.text: (confirming smile, gazing out the window) At the very end. A beat of silence. Bouncing springs. A sudden loud eruption:

dialogues.speaker: TRAPPER
dialogues.text: No! (all turn to look at him; he licks his lips) T have not been to Fort Morgan. I know little of cities. I am a trapper, living mostly alone these last years. But I would descend into town, ever so often, with my pelts. Sell ‘em. And talk, keep m’hand in. Talk. You have got to keep your hand in, talkin. Even if you live in the wild. A moue of agreement from the Frenchman.

dialogues.speaker: FRENCHMAN
dialogues.text: Ees true. Practice.

dialogues.speaker: TRAPPER
dialogues.text: In town I would talk to them was innnarested. Saloon mostly, till I was asked to take m”bidness elsewhere. What sense does that make, there was only the one saloon! The keeper called me tedious. Tedious? Me? (spits the word:) Townsmen. Why, if tidings from the greater world are tedious, if the greater world, not trammeled by... by...  98.

dialogues.speaker: THIGPEN
dialogues.text: a) ... human—

dialogues.speaker: TRAPPER
dialogues.text: (plowing on, unmindful) I would descend from the mountains, not having talked for many months, with much to tell. Much to tell, having stored considerable. Though for many years I was not alone in the wild, I did have a consort, a stout woman of the Hunkpapa Sioux, we had a companionship of sorts but there is a lady present. A life together marked by the passing of the seasons and the corresponding travels of game. In the latter she took little interest—wal, her duties was domestic, I would track and trap and she would tarry hearthside. We did not talk: she did not have English and I am not schooled in the gibberings of the nations. Wal I say we did not talk but we sometimes would, each in our own tongue, often at length, without benefit of understanding the other. But the sound of a human voice is a comfort when you’re cabined up in the woods’n all’d otherwise be but the murmur a wind and the plop a snow from an overloaded branch. I say not understanding each other but twarn’t entirely so, I could often read by means of the tenor of her speech and certain facial expressions the emotional import a what she was sayin and she was often vexed with me, I seldom knew why. And then she moved on.  99. Silence. The passengers in the rattling coach absorb the An afterthought, loudly directed at the lady who is looki which he is oblivious: TRAPPER (CONT’D) There was no issue. Another beat. And then, warmly sympathetic, in an Irish l

dialogues.speaker: CLARENCE
dialogues.text: Did you love her?

dialogues.speaker: TRAPPER
dialogues.text: Oh I don’t know I never even knew her name but I will say this: the nature of them vocal intonations and the play of feelin upon her face helped me to gather that people are like ferrets. Or beaver. One pretty much like the next. Yup all alike I don’t doubt it’s the same even if you travel to Siam.

dialogues.speaker: LADY
dialogues.text: People are not the same. There are two kinds, utterly distinct. Thigpen steps in as moderator: P.

dialogues.speaker: THIGPEN
dialogues.text: What would those be, madam, the two kinds?

dialogues.speaker: FRENCHMAN
dialogues.text: Lucky and unlucky.

dialogues.speaker: CLARENCE
dialogues.text: No, hale’n frail. Difficult to knock to the floor, or wilting.

dialogues.speaker: LADY
dialogues.text: Those are not the two kinds. You well know the two kinds.

dialogues.speaker: TRAPPER
dialogues.text: One kind, ain’t two kinds!—less you mean trapper’n townsman.  100.

dialogues.speaker: LADY
dialogues.text: Upright and sinning. Don’t be a fool.

dialogues.speaker: TRAPPER
dialogues.text: Fool! Yes, I know, tedious fool, you are not the first to lodge that complaint—without grounds. I challenge you for yer credentials madam, fer assessin human worth. People’re like ferrets.

dialogues.speaker: LADY
dialogues.text: People are not like ferrets, and I speak not on my own authority but on that of the holy bible.

dialogues.speaker: TRAPPER
dialogues.text: Wal the bible, people read it diffurnt-—

dialogues.speaker: LADY
dialogues.text: Yes—rightly or wrongly. And here I speak with high authority. My husband, Dr. Betjeman, was an expert, a lecturer at the Chattauqua on moral and spiritual hygiene, now retired. I have the benefit of his insights.

dialogues.speaker: THIGPEN
dialogues.text: Moral hygiene.

dialogues.speaker: LADY
dialogues.text: His lectures were spectacularly attended. He was—he is—considered an expert on spiritual betterment. (¢o trapper) Jacob’s ladder. Betterment. But I don’t suppose you have ever been much occupied with the betterment of your soul.

dialogues.speaker: TRAPPER
dialogues.text: Well, I am not an enemy of betterment. (a beat as he gums) But I am kept very busy with m’traps.  101. The lady gives a mirthless hoot. A rattling silence. At length:

dialogues.speaker: THIGPEN
dialogues.text: Your husband isn’t with you. The lady is prey to sadness. The Frenchman sks.

dialogues.speaker: LADY
dialogues.text: We have been separated for some time. He has been... East. Illness has kept him but now we shall reunite. It will be a great joy.

dialogues.speaker: THIGPEN
dialogues.text: He awaits you in Fort Morgan.

dialogues.speaker: LADY
dialogues.text: Yes. I have been living with my daughter and son-in-law these last three years.

dialogues.speaker: FRENCHMAN
dialogues.text: The parent should not burden the child’s household. This was wrong of you.

dialogues.speaker: LADY
dialogues.text: I was not a burden! I was welcome in my daughter’s house! Her imperiousness belies her own claim, and the Frenchman smile and tilt of his head.

dialogues.speaker: FRENCHMAN
dialogues.text: She would say so, of course. But no doubt you could read in her facial expressions, as pointed out by the tedious man, that your presence was not wanted. We each have a life. Each a life, only our own.

dialogues.speaker: LADY
dialogues.text: You know nothing about me, or my domestic affairs!  102.

dialogues.speaker: FRENCHMAN
dialogues.text: I know that we must each spin our wheel, play our own hand. I was once at cards with a man named Cipolski— this was very many years ago—

dialogues.speaker: TRAPPER
dialogues.text: He a Polack?

dialogues.speaker: FRENCHMAN
dialogues.text: He was Polonaise, yes. And we were-

dialogues.speaker: TRAPPER
dialogues.text: I knew a Polack. The barking interruption nettles the Frenchman. He glares tiresome story to come, but gathers from the ensuing sile the trapper’s digression. The Frenchman draws new breath.

dialogues.speaker: FRENCHMAN
dialogues.text: We were at cards. My hand was poor; I folded. Cipolski and four others remain, but Cipolski says to me, I am in distress, René, you play for me while I perform mes necessités—my necessaries. I say, friend, I cannot wager for you. But of course you can, he says, we know each other well—wager as I would do. But this is quite impossible, no? How a man wagers, it is decided by who he is, by the entirety of his experience of poker up until the moment of that bet. I cannot bet for you. Pourguoi pas? I cannot know you. Not to this degree. We must each play our own hand. No, Cipolski, I say. We may call each other friends, but we cannot know each other so.

dialogues.speaker: TRAPPER
dialogues.text: You can know’m. People are like ferrets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (explosive) People are not like ferrets!

dialogues.speaker: FRENCHMAN
dialogues.text: You misunderstand, son vieux. We can know each other—to a certain level. But to know entirely —smpossible. Poker is interesting because? Because I do not know your hand, yes. But also because—I do not know you. I see what you wager; what does it mean? (a shrug) Ican guess—I cannot know. Or there is no poker.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He leans back smiling, case closed.

dialogues.speaker: LADY
dialogues.text: Poker is a gambling game. You have pursued a life of vice and dissipation—and you are no doubt expert in such pursuits. But no conclusions drawn from such a life, will apply to a life rightly lived. Another shrug and smile from the airily superior Frenchma

dialogues.speaker: FRENCHMAN
dialogues.text: Life is life. Cards will teach you what you need to know. You speak of your life, with your husband who awaits. You fly to him in certainty that he loves you as he did three years ago. Well, three years. There was a flame. You do not know that there is.

dialogues.speaker: LADY
dialogues.text: (heated) Among decent people relations may be eternal. Decent people stay true—to others, to themselves. The Frenchman shakes his head, ¢sting. 103.  The Frenchman smiles. 104.

dialogues.speaker: FRENCHMAN
dialogues.text: Life is change. And all is unknowable. Even my own life: I wager knowing my hand now, not my final hand.

dialogues.speaker: TRAPPER
dialogues.text: Unknowable! But yer talkin like you know more’n the goddamn almanac!

dialogues.speaker: FRENCHMAN
dialogues.text: Tam French.

dialogues.speaker: LADY
dialogues.text: You are a presumptuous man! You tell me my daughter doesn’t love me, that my husband no longer does—

dialogues.speaker: FRENCHMAN
dialogues.text: Ifhe ever did! No offense, Madame, my point is that we never know to the deepest level, and the word “love” can have different meanings.

dialogues.speaker: TRAPPER
dialogues.text: Hold on there, Mister Almanac—

dialogues.speaker: LADY
dialogues.text: I know what “love” means! One thing! You—

dialogues.speaker: FRENCHMAN
dialogues.text: Your husband was an educator; a lecturer; would you say a man of charisma?

dialogues.speaker: LADY
dialogues.text: He was! He is!

dialogues.speaker: FRENCHMAN
dialogues.text: (shrug) Bon, “love” would mean something different to such a person, who commands the love of a crowd, than it would to a person who can only coax love, through subservience.  105.

dialogues.speaker: LADY
dialogues.text: I did not COAX love from Dr. Betjeman! I am nota WHEEDLER. My husband’s love was freely given! And endures!

dialogues.speaker: FRENCHMAN
dialogues.text: His love is different from yours, it’s all I say. The person widely admired accepts love as a tribute. It is his due. He confers his own love as an honor, for, coming from him, it must have great worth. But you, Madame, would not receive that gift, eh, splendidly, as one who has no need, but would grasp at it as a beggar. The lady stares at him aghast. The trapper, looking from her to the Frenchman, fills the

dialogues.speaker: TRAPPER
dialogues.text: Ain’t no call for that kind of talk.

dialogues.speaker: LADY
dialogues.text: How DARE you-

dialogues.speaker: FRENCHMAN
dialogues.text: And of course the great man, the admired man, might well accept other loves, simply as his due, from some of those who admire him. Why not, if the admirer is comely. It is love of a different kind than the domestic of course, but in France we s-AHH!

dialogues.speaker: YOU
dialogues.text: She is batting at him with her furled umbrella. As he par

dialogues.speaker: FRENCHMAN
dialogues.text: Please! Madame!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her frenzy—face white, eyes unblinking, body rigid except with the umbrella—has turned into something else: her eye abruptly drops the umbrella to hook a finger in her high

dialogues.speaker: TRAPPER
dialogues.text: You given her a fit, Frenchie!

dialogues.speaker: THIGPEN
dialogues.text: Oh dear! The lady twists in her seat, gasping. The trapper takes o Clarence, the burly man, takes her free hand in both of h

dialogues.speaker: CLARENCE
dialogues.text: There there, miss, that’s all right, then...

dialogues.speaker: FRENCHMAN
dialogues.text: We—we must stop the coach! Let her walk, move the limbs! Thigpen shakes his head. The information is offhand:

dialogues.speaker: THIGPEN
dialogues.text: Coachman won’t stop.

dialogues.speaker: FRENCHMAN
dialogues.text: He must stop! We are the passengers!

dialogues.speaker: THIGPEN
dialogues.text: Coachman won’t stop. The Frenchman looks at him in brief puzzlement, then stic

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steep down on the Frenchman looking up, wind in his face.

dialogues.speaker: FRENCHMAN
dialogues.text: Coachman! I say, coachman! His steep point-of-view up: the man driving, framed again delineated clouds. The coachman’s face is not much visibl see his coat flowing in the wind; we see his leather glov he raises a whip and snaps it forward through sky; we see brim; we see a flash of full walrus mustache. The Frenchman yells over the wind: FRENCHMAN (CONT’D) .. We must stop! Coachman! A passenger is discommoded!  107. The coachman presents the same windswept picture, driving hearing, or perhaps not listening. The Frenchman pulls his head back inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Frenchman looks around, dazed.

dialogues.speaker: FRENCHMAN
dialogues.text: He will not stop.

dialogues.speaker: THIGPEN
dialogues.text: He never stops. Policy. The lady is somewhat recovered, now limp rather than writ

dialogues.speaker: CLARENCE
dialogues.text: That’s all right, miss... The trapper continues to fan her with his hat as he addre

dialogues.speaker: TRAPPER
dialogues.text: Don’t stop? What if we had to perform necessaries?

dialogues.speaker: THIGPEN
dialogues.text: Have you had to?

dialogues.speaker: TRAPPER
dialogues.text: No—

dialogues.speaker: LADY
dialogues.text: Please... All look to her. Her head is lolled back but she is looki LADY (GONT’D) ... Stop doing that. This arrests the fanning of his hat. The trapper holds it puts it back on. Rattling silence. Then, singing:

dialogues.speaker: VOICE
dialogues.text: As I was a walking down by the loch As I was walking one morning of late (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: VOICE (CONT’D) Who did I spy but my own dear comrade Wrapped up in flannel, so hard was his fate. The lady slowly emerges from her distress to look in wond His rough look would not have led us to expect this beaut The old Irish air he sings is the ancestor—and has the fa Streets of Laredo.”

dialogues.speaker: VOICE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I boldly stepped up to and kindly did ask him Why was he wrapped in flannel so white? My body is injured and sadly disordered All by a young woman, my own heart’s delight. The other passengers, like the lady, are taken out of the the source of the song as sunflowers toward the sun, stru

dialogues.speaker: VOICE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Get six jolly fellows to carry my coffin And six pretty maidens to bear up my pall And give to each of them bunches of roses That they may not smell me as they go along— Hooting sobs. All turn to look: Thigpen is weeping into a handkerchief. He waves their looks away:

dialogues.speaker: THIGPEN
dialogues.text: I’m sorry... I do apologize. He sings it every trip, and it always does this to me. He loudly blows his nose, then stuffs the handkerchief in THIGPEN (CONT’D) .. You’d think, with the business we’re in, I wouldn’t be so—so...

dialogues.speaker: TRAPPER
dialogues.text: What is your business?  109.

dialogues.speaker: THIGPEN
dialogues.text: T like to say that we’re... reapers. Isn’t that right, Clarence?

dialogues.speaker: CLARENCE
dialogues.text: (affirmative musing) ... Harvesters of souls.

dialogues.speaker: THIGPEN
dialogues.text: We help people—who have been adjudged to be, ripe.

dialogues.speaker: TRAPPER
dialogues.text: Whatsat mean? A beat, Thigpen struggling.

dialogues.speaker: THIGPEN
dialogues.text: ... Well... some would call us—Oh, it’s an ugly word-

dialogues.speaker: TRAPPER
dialogues.text: Yer bounty hunters!

dialogues.speaker: THIGPEN
dialogues.text: Literal man! Cruel man! Yes, fine, “bounty hunters,” an ugly title, as ifemolument were the point. It’s an honest calling—is the cobbler not paid for his shoes? I don’t apologize for it, and neither does Clarence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clarence half-nods to confirm, half-shakes to decline to

dialogues.speaker: TRAPPER
dialogues.text: So him on the roof, he was wanted?

dialogues.speaker: THIGPEN
dialogues.text: Mr. Thorpe was very much wanted, judging by what they’re paying for him.

dialogues.speaker: TRAPPER
dialogues.text: What'd he do?

dialogues.speaker: THIGPEN
dialogues.text: Oh I don’t know, does it matter? (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rattling silence. 110. THIGPEN (CONT’D) Just as you said, Madame, there are two kinds of persons. In our business they are: dead, or alive.

dialogues.speaker: CLARENCE
dialogues.text: That’s what they say.

dialogues.speaker: THIGPEN
dialogues.text: But for us it’s a distinction without a difference.

dialogues.speaker: CLARENCE
dialogues.text: Paid either way.

dialogues.speaker: FRENCHMAN
dialogues.text: So you will take zem alive?

dialogues.speaker: THIGPEN
dialogues.text: T didn’t say that. It is punctured by one of the trapper’s eruptions: Clarence is chuckling.

dialogues.speaker: TRAPPER
dialogues.text: I don’t either! Take ‘em alive. Course, not exactly the same business. And I work alone.

dialogues.speaker: THIGPEN
dialogues.text: Oh yes, we’re a duo. A tandem. A team. They’re so easily taken when they’re distracted, people are. So I’m the distractor, with a little story, a little conversation, a song, a sparkle!—and Clarence does the thumping, while their attention is on me.

dialogues.speaker: CLARENCE
dialogues.text: He’s very good, that one. You should see him.

dialogues.speaker: THIGPEN
dialogues.text: No, he’s good.  111.

dialogues.speaker: CLARENCE
dialogues.text: (modest) Ican thump.

dialogues.speaker: THIGPEN
dialogues.text: Mr. Thorpe up there. A typical case. I told him the story of the Midnight Caller. Three loud raps, widely spaced: Thigpen, banging a heel a around, eyes wide. THIGPEN (CONT’D) Someone is outside! Knocking! Oh who can it be! Don’t open it, Mother—what living thing would be out in such a storm! (omiles it away) You know the story, but people can’t get enough of them, the familiar stories, like little children. Because they connect the stories to themselves, I suppose, and we all love hearing about ourselves, over and over. So long as the people in the story are—us, but not us. Not us at the end, especially—the Midnight Caller gets him, never me... I’ll live forever... His reflective look has drifted to the window. Now his at brightly: THIGPEN (CONT’D) ... So I tell the stories. And Clarence thumps.

dialogues.speaker: CLARENCE
dialogues.text: He’s very good. Latening day: it has grown darker in the coach. Everyone to think their thoughts—but they are brought back to him himself, having been working on something:  112.

dialogues.speaker: THIGPEN
dialogues.text: I must say it’s always interesting watching them after Clarence has worked his art. Watching them negotiate the... passage. All eyes are on him.

dialogues.speaker: FRENCHMAN
dialogues.text: ... Pah-sahge? Thigpen looks at the Frenchman.

dialogues.speaker: THIGPEN
dialogues.text: To the other side, here to there. ‘Trying to make sense of it as they pass to that other place. I do like looking into their eyes as they try to make sense of it, I do, I do.

dialogues.speaker: TRAPPER
dialogues.text: ... as they try to make sense of what? After a beat:

dialogues.speaker: THIGPEN
dialogues.text: All of it. More silence. The lady is hesitant to ask, perhaps fearing a negative a

dialogues.speaker: LADY
dialogues.text: And... do they ever... succeed? Thigpen looks at her gravely, considering. He looks at th him, then returns to the lady and smiles.

dialogues.speaker: THIGPEN
dialogues.text: How would I know? I’m only watching.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE FROM OUTSIDE
dialogues.text: Hyah, whoa!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is the coachman stopping the team, as we see from the braking coach.  113. Thigpen looks out.

dialogues.speaker: THIGPEN
dialogues.text: Well—Fort Morgan. I presume we’re all at the hotel? Including Mr. Thorpe—too late to drop him with the sheriff! The window shows that we have stopped square to a hotel. cloudy dusk that paints the exterior all in shades of gra Dead quiet. No people outside, no movement. The only colo motion—is the flickering yellow flame in the gas lights o door. The three passengers looking out show no particular eager is all cheery business, however, and climbs down, followe THIGPEN (CONT’D) ... I suppose Mr. Thorpe will be staying in your room, Clarence. Don’t fancy having him in mine!

dialogues.speaker: CLARENCE
dialogues.text: Whatever you say, guv. The coach shifts with the weight of the coachman who is w ropes being loosed.

dialogues.speaker: THIGPEN
dialogues.text: Or we could sit him in the parlor, a little surprise for the guests in the morning!

dialogues.speaker: CLARENCE
dialogues.text: Give him a newspaper, sir! Anda glass of port! Through the window we see Thigpen and Clarence looking up body off the roof. We hear friction noises, and a canvas towards them feet-first, feet grabbed by Thigpen. The attempted hand-off of upper body to Clarence is fumbl and the body thudding to the ground out of sight.

dialogues.speaker: THIGPEN
dialogues.text: Clumsy fool!  114.

dialogues.speaker: CLARENCE
dialogues.text: Sorry guv.

dialogues.speaker: THIGPEN
dialogues.text: Don’t apologize to me! It’s Mr. Thorpe, isn’t it! They bend out of sight and then straighten with the body. The coach rocks as the coachman descends. Thigpen and Clarence, with the body, lumber into the dept still air their footfalls raise poofs of pale dust which The coachman overtakes them and takes the two steps up to hotel. Thigpen and Clarence’s voices are becoming faint a audible in the dead air: THIGPEN (CONT’D) All joking aside, your room, I think, Clarence.

dialogues.speaker: CLARENCE
dialogues.text: Ifyou say so, sir.

dialogues.speaker: THIGPEN
dialogues.text: No worries about him snoring!

dialogues.speaker: CLARENCE
dialogues.text: I’m not worried, sir.

dialogues.speaker: THIGPEN
dialogues.text: (affectionate) You never worry. One of your virtues.

dialogues.speaker: CLARENCE
dialogues.text: T’anks very much. The passengers are watching. No one yet moves to get out. A creak of the hotel door opening, the coachman holding i He follows them in and closes the door behind. Nothing of revealed. We have stayed with the passengers and in their perspecti at, they look uneasily among themselves. The trapper, by the coach door on the hotel side, gesture  115.

dialogues.speaker: TRAPPER
dialogues.text: Go on ahead. The Frenchman runs his tongue over his lips.

dialogues.speaker: FRENCHMAN
dialogues.text: Apres vous. The trapper casts about. To the lady:

dialogues.speaker: TRAPPER
dialogues.text: Ladies first. She is no more inclined than he. She comes up with:

dialogues.speaker: LADY
dialogues.text: .. I must be helped down. The trapper clears his throat, reaches for the door, paus pushes it open and steps gingerly down. He turns back and extends a hand up to the lady. She cann there is nothing for the Frenchman to do but follow. The three head single file—lady leading, trapper second, the hotel. Outside, their faces—now that they are no long of the stagecoach—are somewhat pale. The hotel’s front door creaks open, the coachman emerges. and then past them, all coat and gloves and boots—hardly of eyes between the low hatbrim and the great mustache. The three passengers ascend to the boardwalk. The lady dr front door but doesn’t reach for it. An uneasy beat as we hear the coachman, off, clambering b Finally: LADY (CONT’D) Will someone open the door for a lady? My husband is waiting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The trapper opens it.  116. Visible past the three, the hotel interior. Its light lie in the parlor give a feel of the heavy Victorian furnitur Though each light is low, they seem to have great depth: There is a staircase to the right with a burgundy runner. we can see Thigpen and Clarence awkwardly climbing, the c

dialogues.speaker: THIGPEN
dialogues.text: . and... step and... step and... step and... The trapper follows the lady in, and the Frenchman is abo look is drawn by a whipcrack.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE
dialogues.text: Hyah! We hold on the Frenchman looking out at the street and th hear, the stagecoach turning. The Frenchman’s eyes track way it came, with the jingle of tack and the cries of the hooves. The sound fades. The Frenchman, trying to maintain his lofty insouciance—a succeeding—turns, enters the hotel, and closes the door b
